# Preface {-}

This is an R Markdown Notebook documenting how the codes in the [happyr](https://gederajeg.github.io/happyr/) package [@rajeg_happyr_2018] are used for the statistical analyses in Rajeg's [-@rajeg_metaphorical_2018] [PhD thesis](http://doi.org/10.26180/5cac231a97fb1). The study focuses on metaphors for `r happyr::scaps("happiness")` near-synonyms in Indonesian. The underlying R Markdown (.Rmd) file of the notebook also includes the in-line codes to generate numeric results in the chunks of the body-text of the relevant chapters. Thus, not all body-text of the thesis are included in this notebook. Note that there can be some differences in the wordings and arrangement between the narative in this notebook and in the final version of the thesis, but not with the quantitative analysis.

# Codes for Chapter 3 - Interrater Agreement

## Results for *constructional patterns*
```{r kappa-cxn-computation}
# kappa calculation
irr_cxn <- happyr::kappa_tidy(df = happyr::df_cxn_pattern,
                              var_names = "^pattern",
                              round = "pre_disc")
```


The Kappa scores in [Table \@ref(tab:kappa-cxn)](#kappa-cxn) for the constructional pattern annotation show high level of agreements for the first round (i.e., the pre-disc[ussion stage]) ($\mu$^[The Greek symbol "$\mu$" stands for 'mean' or 'average' score, meanwhile "$\sigma$" stands for 'standard deviation' score.] = `r mean(irr_cxn[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`, $\sigma$ = `r sd(irr_cxn[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`).

```{r kappa-cxn}
# print the result of interrater-agreement for the construction
irr_cxn %>%
  mutate(words = paste("*", words, "*", sep = ""),
         gloss = c("happiness", "joy", "pleasure"),
         kappa = round(kappa, 2L)) %>% 
  select(words, gloss, everything()) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = "Cohen's Kappa for the Constructional Patterns identification", row.names = TRUE)
```

[Figure \@ref(fig:kappa-cxn-figure)](#kappa-cxn-figure) summarises the distribution of the most frequent constructional patterns for the agreed cases, occurring at least five tokens.

```{r kappa-cxn-figure, fig.width=7, fig.asp=0.7}
happyr::plot_cxn_interrater(df = happyr::top_cxn_data) +
  labs(title = expression(paste("Distribution of the constructional patterns for the agreed cases (", N["patterns"] >= "5)", sep = "")),
       caption = "The values inside the bars are the patterns' token frequencies")
```

The values inside the bars represents the token frequency of the patterns. The '`r happyr::scaps("lex")`-…' part in the legend indicates the syntactic, constructional collocates of the target domain words (the 'T-…' part) that potentially evoke the metaphorical source frames. The constructional patterns in the legend are in descending order from the most to the least frequent types among these top constructions. These types are exemplified in order below.

(@cxn1) *Bagi konsumen yang __memburu__ kesenangan sesaat* (`r happyr::scaps('lex')`-verb_T-dobj) (ind_newscrawl2011_1M:621419) 
(@cxn2) *kebahagiaan __memuncak__ setelah para penari dan penonton memainkan permainan seremonial kuno* (T-subj_`r happyr::scaps('lex')`-verb) (ind_newscrawl2012_1M:910372) 
(@cxn3) *menjadikan manusia sebagai __budak__ kesenangan* (`r happyr::scaps('lex')`-noun_T-noun) (ind_newscrawl2012_1M:7767)
(@cxn4) *__dalam__ kesenangan tentu ada kesusahannya* (`r happyr::scaps('lex')`-prep_T-noun) (ind_web2012_1M:302089)
(@cxn5) *hidup dunia sangatlah penting kalau dijadikan persiapan untuk kebahagiaan __akhirat__* (T-noun_`r happyr::scaps('lex')`-noun) (ind_mixed2012_1M:406885)

## Results for *metaphoricity* of the patterns

The next task is to identify whether the extracted and _agreed_ constructional patterns of the synonyms evoke metaphorical readings or not. For this task, we expected the agreement would be lower than in the previous task as determining metaphorical usages is more subjective. The results are shown in [Table \@ref(tab:kappa-metaphor)](#kappa-metaphor).

```{r kappa-metaphor}
# kappa calculation first round
irr_use_1 <- happyr::kappa_tidy(df = happyr::df_meta_use_1st,
                                var_names = "^use_(coder|author)$",
                                round = "pre_disc") %>% 
  mutate(words = paste("*", words, "*", sep = ""),
         gloss = c("happiness", "joy", "pleasure"),
         kappa = round(kappa, 2L)) %>% 
  select(words, gloss, everything())

# kappa calculation second round
irr_use_2 <- happyr::kappa_tidy(df = happyr::df_meta_use_2nd,
                                var_names = "^use_2nd_",
                                round = "post_disc") %>% 
  mutate(words = paste("*", words, "*", sep = ""),
         gloss = c("happiness", "joy", "pleasure"),
         kappa = round(kappa, 2L)) %>% 
  select(words, gloss, everything())

irr_use_2 %>% 
  bind_rows(irr_use_1) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = "Cohen's Kappa for the Metaphor Identification (post- and pre-discussion stages)", row.names = TRUE)
```

In the first round, as expected, the average agreement across the three synonyms is moderate ($\mu$ = `r mean(irr_use_1[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`, $\sigma$ = `r sd(irr_use_1[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`). Differences were resolved in the discussion round.

One of the prominent differences is that the second coder annotated patterns referring to `r happyr::scaps('temporal')` aspect of the synonyms as metaphorical, while `r happyr::scaps('time')` itself is often understood in metaphorical concepts [e.g., @boroditsky_roles_2002]. The patterns include *NP~emo~ __abadi__* '_eternal_ NP~emo~', *NP~emo~ __ditunda__* 'NP~emo~ _be delayed/postponed_, *__menunda__ NP~emo~* 'to _delay/postpone_ NP~emo~', *NP~emo~ __bertahan/berlangsung lama__* 'NP~emo~ _lasts long_', *NP~emo~ __berlangsung sesaat__* 'NP~emo~ *lasts for a while*', and *NP~emo~ hanya __sementara__* 'NP~emo~ is just _for a while_'.

...

With the remaining unresolved differences, the second Kappa was calculated, and the mean Kappa increases to substantial agreement ($\mu$ = `r mean(irr_use_2[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`, $\sigma$ = `r sd(irr_use_2[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`).

## Results for *conceptual metaphors*

Coding for the conceptual metaphors is based on the agreed constructional patterns that have also been agreed to be metaphorical [@shutova_conceptual_2013, p. 1275]. [Table \@ref(tab:kappa-cm)](#kappa-cm) presents the results for this classification.

```{r kappa-cm}
# kappa calculation first round
irr_cm_1 <- happyr::kappa_tidy(df = happyr::df_cm,
                                var_names = "_pre$",
                                round = "pre_disc") %>% 
  mutate(words = paste("*", words, "*", sep = ""),
         gloss = c("happiness", "joy", "pleasure"),
         kappa = round(kappa, 2L)) %>% 
  select(words, gloss, everything())

# kappa calculation second round
irr_cm_2 <- happyr::kappa_tidy(df = happyr::df_cm,
                                var_names = "_post$",
                                round = "post_disc") %>% 
  mutate(words = paste("*", words, "*", sep = ""),
         gloss = c("happiness", "joy", "pleasure"),
         kappa = round(kappa, 2L)) %>% 
  select(words, gloss, everything())

irr_cm_2 %>% 
  bind_rows(irr_cm_1) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = "Cohen's Kappa for the Conceptual Metaphor coding (post- and pre-discussion stages)", row.names = TRUE)
```

In the first round, the average Kappa is moderate ($\mu$ = `r mean(irr_cm_1[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`, $\sigma$ = `r sd(irr_cm_1[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`). Discrepancies occur predominantly with regards to determining the level of granularity for the (mnemonic labels of the) metaphors, the decision of which requires subjective interpretation.

...

With the remaining unresolved disagreement after discussion, the second round Kappas were computed. On average, the agreement level has increased to "nearly perfect" agreement ($\mu$ = `r mean(irr_cm_2[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`, $\sigma$ = `r sd(irr_cm_2[["kappa"]]) %>% round(2L)`). Despite this increased agreement level after discussion, after all, any metaphor studies are always permeated by certain degree of subjectivity. In practice, it means that CMT analysts/practicioners can have disagreement over certain analyses, be it when determining whether an expression is metaphorical or not, or when grouping a set of metaphorical expressions into certain conceptual metaphor categories.

# Codes for Chapter 5 - Entrenched metaphors

```{r ttr, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}
# calculation for the token, type, and type/token ratios data
ttr_metaphor <- happyr::ttr(df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor,
                            schema_var = "metaphors",
                            lexunit_var = "lu",
                            float_digits = 2)
```

```{r perc-of-discussed-metaphor, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE}
# Tokens proportion of the discussed metaphors
creative_metaphors_length <- ttr_metaphor %>% 
  arrange(desc(type_per_token_lu)) %>% 
  filter(token >= 3) %>% 
  top_n(10, type_per_token_lu) %>% 
  select(metaphors, token, type_lu, type_per_token_lu) %>% 
  dim() %>% 
  .[1]

creative_metaphors_prop <- ttr_metaphor %>% 
  arrange(desc(type_per_token_lu)) %>% 
  filter(token >= 3) %>% 
  top_n(10, type_per_token_lu) %>% 
  tally(perc_token) %>% 
  .$n

top_token_metaphor <- ttr_metaphor %>% 
  top_n(10, token) %>% 
  .[,1] %>% 
  unlist() %>% 
  unname()

top_type_metaphor <- ttr_metaphor %>% 
  top_n(10, type_lu) %>% 
  .[,1] %>% 
  unlist() %>% 
  unname()

entrenched_metaphors_prop <- ttr_metaphor %>% 
  top_n(10, token) %>% 
  tally(perc_token) %>% 
  .$n

productive_metaphors_length <- setdiff(top_type_metaphor, top_token_metaphor) %>% 
  length()

productive_metaphors_prop <- ttr_metaphor %>% 
  top_n(10, type_lu) %>% 
  arrange(desc(type_lu)) %>% 
  filter(token < 100) %>% 
  tally(perc_token) %>% 
  .$n
```

## Introduction

...

For this thesis, I analysed 4580^[These are tokens after manual duplicates-removal.] usage samples of sentences containing words referring to five central members under the generic `r happyr::scaps('happiness')`-like category in Indonesian [cf. @shaver_structure_2001]. The analysis results in the total `r sum(ttr_metaphor$token)` tokens of metaphorical linguistic expressions containing `r dim(ttr_metaphor)[1]` metaphor types.

...

This chapter discusses the top-10 most frequent conceptual metaphors (`r section`[\@ref(frequentmetaphors)](#frequentmetaphors)), constituting `r entrenched_metaphors_prop`% of the total metaphorical tokens; Chapter 6 discusses `r productive_metaphors_prop + creative_metaphors_prop`% of the total `r sum(ttr_metaphor$token)` tokens, consisting of `r productive_metaphors_length+creative_metaphors_length` different metaphor types. In total, Chapter 5 and Chapter 6 account for `r productive_metaphors_prop + creative_metaphors_prop + entrenched_metaphors_prop`% of the total `r sum(ttr_metaphor$token)` tokens of the metaphorical expressions.

...

## Top-10 frequent metaphors for `r scaps("happiness")` in Indonesian {#frequentmetaphors}

This section discuss which metaphors are relatively entrenched for `r scaps("happiness")` in Indonesian, based on their token frequency [cf. @hilpert_keeping_2006, pp. 130-131]. I focus on the ten most frequent metaphors as shown in [Table \@ref(tab:top-10-frequent-metaphors)](#top-10-frequent-metaphors).

```{r top-10-frequent-metaphors}
ttr_metaphor %>% 
  top_n(10, token) %>% 
  select(metaphors, token, perc_token) %>% 
  mutate(metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  rename(Metaphors = metaphors,
         Token = token,
         `%Token` = perc_token) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 metaphors sorted in descending order of the token frequency.', row.names = TRUE)
```

As [Table \@ref(tab:top-10-frequent-metaphors)](#top-10-frequent-metaphors) shows, `r scaps('happiness')` is most frequently construed as a `r scaps('possessable object')`. The following sub-sections elaborate on the submappings and the inferences evoked for construing aspects of `r scaps('happiness')`. While the discussion begins with the `r scaps('happiness is a possessable object')` metaphor, it may not fully follow the ranked-order of the metaphors in [Table \@ref(tab:top-10-frequent-metaphors)](#top-10-frequent-metaphors). Instead, metaphors conveying related themes will follow from one another in the discussion to highlight similarities. For instance, the aspect of intensity is highlighted mainly by `r scaps('contained entity, liquid in a container')`, and `r scaps('quantity of object')` metaphors. These three metaphors are accordingly presented in sequence, despite their non-successive ranking in [Table \@ref(tab:top-10-frequent-metaphors)](#top-10-frequent-metaphors).

### Happiness is a possessable object {#possession}

```{r possession-data-for-bodytext}
lu_possessable <- happyr::get_lu_table("possessable",
                                       top_n_only = FALSE,
                                       df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor,
                                       incl_submappings = TRUE,
                                       submapping_perc = TRUE)

possess_frames <- happyr::get_frames("possessable",
                                     df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

possess_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("possessable",
                                               df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'caus'), 'cause', 'existence'),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'attain'), 'attainment', aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'change of '), 'ceasing', aspect))

possess_submappings_aspect <- possess_submappings %>% 
  group_by(aspect) %>% 
  summarise(n = sum(n), 
            type = sum(type)) %>% 
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2), 
         type_perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(n))
```

...

The cause of `r scaps("happiness")` is referred to via interrelated frames evoking `r scaps("object transfer")`. They are (i) the `r scaps("offering")` frame (`r possess_frames %>% filter(frames=='offering') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`% of the total tokens of the `r scaps("possessable object")` metaphor), which in *FrameNet* is described as adopting the structure of `r scaps("giving")` frame; (ii) the `r scaps("giving")` frame (`r possess_frames %>% filter(frames=='giving') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%); (iii) `r scaps("dispersal")`, which is related to `r scaps("resource transfer")` frame in *MetaNet* (`r possess_frames %>% filter(frames=='dispersal') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%); and (iv) the generic `r scaps("caused motion")` frame (`r possess_frames %>% filter(frames=='caused motion') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), which includes the `r scaps("bringing")` frame.

...

From the perspective of the Recipient, receiving or gaining the transferred possessable object is mapped onto the onset of `r scaps("happiness")`. This inference is evoked through the `r scaps("gain possession")` frame (`r possess_frames %>% filter(frames=='gain possession') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%). The frame is available in the MN frame repository.

...

The experience of happiness can be expressed as the gaining of a possessabe object, invoked through the `r scaps("possession")` frame (`r possess_frames %>% filter(frames=='possession') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%).

...

[Table \@ref(tab:possessable-object-lu-table)](#possessable-object-lu-table) shows the LU types most frequently co-occur with the `r scaps('happiness')` words to evoke the `r scaps(tolower('POSSESSABLE OBJECT'))` metaphor and its frame-based submappings.

```{r possessable-object-lu-table}
happyr::get_lu_table("possessable object", 
                     top_n_only = TRUE,
                     df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a possessable object</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```


Percentage overall in the LU table indicates the percentage of a given LU from the total tokens of the metaphor.

*Beri(kan)* 'to give', for instance, is the most frequent LU for the `r scaps("giving")` frame (`r lu_possessable[grep('beri\\(kan\\)', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()`% of the total tokens of the `r scaps("giving")` frame), compared to *kembalikan* 'to give sth. back; to return sth.' (`r lu_possessable[grep('kembalikan', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()` %). For `r scaps("gain possession")` frame, *dapat(kan)*^[I put the 'v' tag for *dapat(kan)* 'to get' since the form *dapat* has another function as an abilitative modal auxiliary 'to be able to; can'.] 'to get' (`r lu_possessable[grep('dapat\\(kan\\)', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()`%) is the most frequent LU. *Berbagi* 'to share' is the most common LU (`r lu_possessable[grep('berbagi', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()`%) for the `r scaps("dispersal")` frame, while *miliki* 'to have/own' (`r lu_possessable[grep('miliki', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()`%) and *kehilangan* 'to lose' (`r lu_possessable[grep('kehilangan', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()`%) are representative for the `r scaps("possession")` and `r scaps("lose possession")` frames respectively. Lastly, *bawa(kan)* 'to bring sth. (to sb.)' (`r lu_possessable[grep('bawa\\(kan\\)', lu_possessable$Lexical_units, perl = T), 6] %>% unlist()`%) is the most frequent LU for the `r scaps("caused motion")` frame. 

Despite its high token frequency, `r scaps("happiness is a possessable object")` has a low degree of lexical diversity in its linguistic expressions given its token frequency. The metaphor is expressed with different LU types in only `r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles('possessable', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor) %>% .[,2] %>% unlist()`% of the total `r filter(ttr_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "possessable object$"))[["token"]]` tokens. The percentage is derived from dividing the type frequency of the metaphor with its token frequency (i.e. the *type/token ratio* (TTR) measure) and normalising it into percentage [cf. @stefanowitsch_corpus_2017, p. 282]. The TTR value of `r scaps(tolower('POSSESSABLE OBJECT'))` indicates that it is evoked by a few yet highly frequent and conventional metaphorical expressions.

Overall, the predominant submappings in the `r scaps("possessable object")` metaphor are those involving (potential) object transfers (`r possess_submappings_aspect %>% filter(aspect=='cause') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`% of the total `r filter(ttr_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "possessable object$"))[["token"]]` tokens of the metaphor), highlighting the cause for `r scaps("happiness")`. It is then followed by the receiving of the possessable object, hence the attainment of `r scaps("happiness")` (`r possess_submappings_aspect %>% filter(aspect=='attainment') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%); the possessing, or existence, (`r possess_submappings_aspect %>% filter(aspect=='existence') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%); and lastly the losing, or ceasing, of `r scaps("happiness")` (`r possess_submappings_aspect %>% filter(aspect=='ceasing') %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%).

### Happiness is a desired goal {#desired-goal}

```{r destination-data-for-bodytext}
goal_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("desired", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'reaching|capturing|grasping|finding'), 'attaining', 'process'),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'access|aids'), 'means', aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'end of a path'), 'goal', aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'impeding'), 'obstacle', aspect)) %>%
  group_by(aspect) %>%
  mutate(perc_aspect_by_submet = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2),
         type_perc_aspect_by_submet = round(type/sum(type) * 100, 2)) %>%
  ungroup()

goal_aspect <- goal_submappings %>%
  group_by(aspect) %>%
  summarise(n = sum(n), type = sum(type)) %>%
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2), 
         type_perc = round(type/sum(type) * 100, 2)) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

# Semantic types of the PURSUIT event
searching_lu <- c("cari", "pencarian", "jemput(lah)", "gali", "pendulang", "sasaran")
searching_lu_token <- dim(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, lu %in% searching_lu))[1]

chasing_lu <- c("kejar", "pengejaran")
chasing_lu_token <- dim(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, lu %in% chasing_lu))[1]

hunting_lu <- c("pemburu", "buruan", "memburu")
hunting_lu_token <- dim(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, lu %in% hunting_lu))[1]

# pursue semantics table
pursue_semantics <- data.frame(semantics = c("searching", "chasing", "hunting"), 
                               n = c(searching_lu_token, chasing_lu_token, hunting_lu_token), 
                               type = c(length(searching_lu), length(chasing_lu), length(hunting_lu))) %>%
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2),
         type_perc = round(type/sum(type) * 100, 2))

# grammatical voice of verbal lexical units for the metaphor
voice_destination <- happyr::phd_data_metaphor %>% 
  filter(str_detect(metaphors, "desired"), 
         lu_phrase_type == "vp") %>% 
  group_by(voice_verbal_lu, submappings) %>% 
  summarise(n = n(), 
            type_per_voice = n_distinct(lu)) %>% 
  arrange(submappings, desc(n)) %>% 
  group_by(submappings) %>% 
  mutate(perc_voice_by_submet = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2), 
         perc_type = round(type_per_voice/sum(type_per_voice) * 100, 2))

voice_destination_max <- voice_destination %>% 
  filter(n == max(n)) %>% 
  ungroup()

voice_destination_summary <- voice_destination %>% 
  group_by(voice_verbal_lu) %>% 
  summarise(n = sum(n), type_per_voice = sum(type_per_voice)) %>% 
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2),
         perc_type_per_voice = round(type_per_voice/sum(type_per_voice) * 100, 2)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(perc))
```

In `r section`[\@ref(possession)](#possession), `r scaps("happiness")` is understood as an object caused to move to the Goal, namely the candidate Experiencer, via various kinds of transferring scenes. In this sense, the candidate Experiencer takes a rather passive role in acquiring the possession. In contrast, `r scaps(tolower("HAPPINESS IS A DESIRED GOAL"))` construes `r scaps("happiness")` as a location or object towards which the candidate Experiencer moves, reflecting the `r scaps("quest")` metaphors family proposed by Stefanowitsch [-@stefanowitsch_happiness_2004] [cf. @lakoff_philosophy_1999, pp. 196-197].

`r scaps("Happiness is a desired goal")` consists of submappings built upon structures of the `r scaps("self-propelled motion to a destination")` frame [cf. @lakoff_philosophy_1999, pp. 190-191]. The submappings provide rich inferences concerning (i) `r scaps("happiness")` as an aspiration (e.g. a desired object or location), (ii) process and means to achieve the aspiration, as well as (iii) how the process may be halted. Citations (@tujuan) to (@berujung) illustrate the mapping of `r scaps("happiness")` onto the Goal role. The metaphorical expressions are based on lexical units (LUs) that evoke the schematic image of the <span `r scaps("source-path-goal")` (SPG) frame.

(@tujuan) example for _tujuan_ (ind_newscrawl2012_1M:192777)
(@bermuara) example for _bermuara ke ujung_ (ind_newscrawl2011_1M:667627)
(@berujung) example for _berujung pada_ (ind_newscrawl2012_1M:536251)

The SPG frame describes a series of locational roles, namely Source, Path, and Goal, along which an entity, called Trajector, moves, or is conceived as moving^[See *MetaNet* (MN) and *FrameNet*'s (FN) definition of `r scaps('source-path-goal')` frame in their respective frame repository.]. When the frame is used for designating `r scaps("happiness is a desired goal")` metaphor, `r scaps("happiness")` is mapped onto the Goal role. That is, `r scaps("happiness")` is understood as the Goal-end of a Path, towards which the Trajector may move along from a Source.

Concerning the conceptualisations of the attempt for achieving `r scaps("happiness")`, there are several relevant frames. Two of these frames indicate the means that are required by the Mover in h(is/er) attempt to reach the Goal; these frames are the `r scaps("access to a location")` (as in (@kunci) to (@tiket)) and `r scaps("guided motion")` frames (as in (@guide) and (@guide1)). When mapped onto the target frame, the inference from these two frames indicates that `r scaps('happiness')` cannot be directly achieved without certain means, such as access or guidance.

(@kunci) example for _kunci_ (ind_mixed2012_1M:424589)
(@pintu) example for _pintu_ (ind_web2011_300K:108339)
(@tiket) example for _ticket_ (ind_mixed2012_1M:397320)
(@guide) example for `r scaps("guided motion")` frame with _mengantarkan_ (ind_web2012_1M:358204)
(@guide1) example for `r scaps("guided motion")` frame with _memimpin ke jalan_ (ind_newscrawl2012_1M:872312)

Next, the attempt by the candidate Experiencer to achieve `r scaps("happiness")` is conceptualised via `r scaps("purposeful action is self-propelled motion to a destination")` metaphor, based on the `r scaps('self-propelled motion to a destination')` frame^[See https://metaphor.icsi.berkeley.edu/pub/en/index.php/Frame:Self_propelled_motion_to_a_destination (Last access: 15 August 2018).]. The metaphor is composed of two more basic metaphors. The first of these is `r scaps("action is self-propelled motion")` (e.g. She *squeezed her way to* thinner thighs^[Taken from https://metaphor.icsi.berkeley.edu/pub/en/index.php/Metaphor:ACTION_IS_SELF-PROPELLED_MOTION_ALONG_A_PATH (Last access: 15 August 2018).]), which is grounded on the correlation of doing actions and moving. The metaphor also indicates that the Mover has his/her own control over the direction of its action/motion; yet, as can be seen from examples (@guide) and (@guide1) above, the movement can also be taken over, or guided, by a co-Mover. The second constituting metaphor is `r scaps("purposes are destination")` (e.g. We have *taken the first step*), which is grounded on the correlation of reaching a destination with achieving a purpose (e.g. going to a cafe for a coffee) [@lakoff_philosophy_1999, pp. 52-53, 187-191].


In the `r scaps('self-propelled motion to a destination')` frame, the Goal role is profiled as a desirable goal, which is not inferred from its parent frame, namely `r scaps("motion to a location")`; this parent frame profiles only the goal-oriented motion. The metaphor based on `r scaps('self-propelled motion to a destination')` frame suggests that becoming happy constitutes a purposeful attempt due to the desirability of the Goal (cf. (@motiontolocation) and (@kembali)). Moreover, the person aiming to be happy needs to take certain action, hence movement, to realise this purpose. Indonesian voice morphology can contribute to the agentive construal of the candidate Experiencer in the metaphor. Agentivity can be inferred from the verbal LUs of the metaphor that most frequently occur in active voice construction that, in Indonesian, can be marked by prefix *meN-* (`r dplyr::filter(voice_destination_summary, str_detect(voice_verbal_lu, '^active'))$perc`% of the total `r sum(voice_destination_summary$n)` tokens of the verbal LUs for the metaphor) (see, for instance, (@motiontolocation), (@search), and (@chase)).

(@motiontolocation) example with motion to a destination with *menuju* (ind_web2012_1M:398400)
(@kembali) example with *kembali ke* (ind_newscrawl2011_1M:451099)

The number of tokens for the `r scaps('self-propelled motion to a destination')` frame only accounts for (`r dplyr::filter(goal_submappings, grepl("process", aspect) & grepl("motion", submappings))[[7]]`%) of the total `r sum(dplyr::filter(goal_submappings, grepl("process", aspect))[["n"]])` tokens referring to the attempt to be happy. This is predominantly expressed by the verb *menuju* 'to head to a location' as in (@motiontolocation) above. A preferable frame for conceptualising the attempt constitutes the subcase of the `r scaps("self-propelled motion to a destination")`, namely the `r scaps("pursue")` frame (`r dplyr::filter(goal_submappings, grepl("process", aspect) & grepl("pursu", submappings))[[7]]`% of the total frequency for expressions evoking the attempt aspect).

The *subcase of relation* in *MetaNet* (MN) indicates that `r scaps("pursue")` fully incorporates the frame elements and inferential structures of its parent frame (i.e. `r scaps("self-propelled motion to a destination")`), such as the desirability of the Goal, Self-motion_x-schema/process, and the Mover. In addition, `r scaps("pursue")` as the child frame may have semantic specification, or elaboration, of the frame role parameters. However, MN repository has not yet provided these detailed specifications that may distinguish the `r scaps("pursue")` frame from its parent frame. Perhaps, `r scaps("pursue")` elaborates the semantics of the Self-motion_x-schema with more specific means of action undertaken to achieve the goal, such as searching (@search), chasing (@chase), or hunting (@hunt). Meanwhile, the `r scaps("self-propelled motion to a destination")` may only profile a self-initiated motion of the Mover-actor until (s)he reaches the destination. No specific means are implied in this frame for how the Goal is reached^[No relevant lexical units are given in the entry of `r scaps("self-propelled motion to a destination")` frame. See https://metaphor.icsi.berkeley.edu/pub/en/index.php/Frame:Self_propelled_motion_to_a_destination (Last access: 9 September 2018).] and for whether the Goal is static or moving.

(@search) example with *mencari* (searching) (ind_mixed2012_1M:397221)
(@chase) example with *mengejar* (chasing) (ind_mixed2012_1M:504905)
(@hunt) example with *pemburu* (hunting) (ind_newscrawl2011_1M:79925)

The lexical units (LUs) within `r scaps("pursue")` represent three categories of semantic type. They are LUs referring to `r scaps("searching")` (`r dplyr::filter(pursue_semantics, str_detect(semantics, "searching"))[["perc"]]`% of the total `r sum(pursue_semantics$n)` tokens of expressions evoking `r happyr::scaps("pursue")`), `r scaps("chasing")` (`r dplyr::filter(pursue_semantics, str_detect(semantics, "chasing"))[["perc"]]`%), and `r scaps("hunting")` (`r dplyr::filter(pursue_semantics, str_detect(semantics, "hunting"))[["perc"]]`%). The preference for the searching process portrays `r scaps("happiness")` as something hidden and requiring exploration for its attainment. Intuitively, _mengejar_ 'to chase; run after' in example (@chase) may invite an image of (i) a moving, desired Goal, and (ii) having an immediate expectation by the Self-mover when chasing the Goal. In the target frame, this inference maps onto the exigency for experiencing `r scaps("happiness")`. After all, examples (@search) to (@hunt) clearly single out the active role of the Self-mover in achieving the Goal. In the target frame, this inference corresponds to the active responsibility of the candidate Experiencer for h(is/er) own `r scaps("happiness")`.

A small number (i.e. `r dplyr::filter(goal_aspect, aspect == "obstacle")$perc`%) of the tokens of the `r scaps("happiness is a desired goal")` metaphor evoke submapping conveying potential inhibition on the attempt to achieve `r scaps("happiness")`. Example (@tahan) specifies a self-internal inhibition for certain prohibited pleasure.

(@tahan) example with *menahan* diri *dari* beragam __kesenangan__ (ind_web2011_300K:118298)

Within the arc of the `r scaps("happiness is a desired goal")` metaphor, the achievement of `r scaps("happiness")` is conceptualised as the final stage of the motion. This could be reaching/arriving (@capai), locating/finding (@temukan), and capturing/grasping (@raih) the desired goal [cf. @stefanowitsch_happiness_2004, pp. 142-145].

(@capai) example with *mencapai* (ind_mixed2012_1M:263518)
(@temukan) example with *menemukan* (ind_mixed2012_1M:565135)
(@raih) example with *meraih* (ind_web2012_1M:152154)

All the source frame LUs conveying the final stage of the motion process indicate that a prior effort is required by the Mover before (s)he can reach or capture h(is/er) desired Goal. This inference maps onto the efforts required for somebody to be happy.

```{r desired-goal-lu-table}
get_lu_table("desired", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a desired goal</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

`r scaps("Happiness is a desired goal")` has little variation in its linguistic expressions, showing only `r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles('desired', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor)[[2]]`% variation given its overall token frequency (`r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles('desired', token, df = ttr_metaphor)[[2]]` tokens). The percentage of the submapping indicating the attempt to attain `r scaps('happiness')` is only slightly higher (`r dplyr::filter(goal_aspect, aspect == "process")$perc`%) than the attainment (`r dplyr::filter(goal_aspect, aspect == "attaining")$perc`%). This distribution suggests that the process to and the attainment of `r scaps("happiness")` are relatively equally highlighted in the sample.

## Happiness is a location {#location}

```{r location-data-for-maintext}
location_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("a location$", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'motion into'), 'change of state into', 'being in a state'),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, '(moving away|being far) from'), 'change of state out', aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'caused'), 'caused change of state to', aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'is a (landmark|bounded entity|geographic|source of a path|location$)'), 'location state', aspect))

# get the LU table
location_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("is a location$",
                                    top_n_only = TRUE,
                                    df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)
```

`r scaps("Happiness is a location")` is a subcase of one of the central metaphors in the *Location Event Structure Metaphor* (LESM) system, i.e. `r scaps("states are location")` [@lakoff_philosophy_1999, pp. 179-180]. The metaphor is centred around the `r scaps('location')`-related frames, such as the `r scaps("being at a location")` frame. This frame schematically describes a scene where a trajector (i.e. the Located_thing role) occupies a location (i.e. the Current_location role). The use of the frame in `r scaps("happiness is a location")` sees the role-mappings of (i) the target frame `r scaps('happiness')` onto the Current_location role of the source frame and (ii) the candidate Experiencer onto the Located_thing role. 

The principal inference invited by `r scaps("happiness is a location")` is that the experience of `r scaps("happiness")` is expressed as the experiencer’s being located at the `r scaps("happiness")`-location. The experiencer is thus depicted as the Located_thing. The metaphor tends to be expressed via prepositional phrase whose nominal object slot is filled with the `r scaps("happiness")` nouns. This nominal object slot is linked to the Current_location role. The most frequent preposition is *dalam* 'inside' (cf. (@dalam)). 

(@dalam) example with *dalam* (ind_newscrawl2011_1M:512071)

*Dalam* indicates that the Current_location role is a bounded region with interior and exterior. The `r scaps("bounded region")` frame evokes a more specific inference compared to the unbounded location version (as in (@di) and (@pada) below). Being happy maps onto being in the interior of the bounded region, while unhappy is mapped onto the exterior.

(@di) example with *di __keceriaan__* (Kompas via WebCorp:40)
(@pada) example with *pada* suatu *__kegembiraan__* (ind_mixed2012_1M:194551)

The same idea indicated in (@dalam) to (@pada) can be expressed by the collocation of the prepositions with stative, locational verbs. The verbs add temporal aspect, indicating that the Experiencer is in an ongoing Location-state. The nature of the preposition will tell us whether the location is a bounded region (as in (@beradadalam) to (@berteduhdalam)) or underspecified for its interior-exteriority (as in (@beradapada)). The submapping of `r scaps("being happy as being at a location")` exemplified in (@dalam)-(@beradapada) takes up the majority of the metaphor's token (`r sum(filter(location_submappings, str_detect(submappings, "being (in|at)"))[["perc"]])`% out of `r sum(location_submappings$n)` tokens of `r scaps("happiness is a location")`). 

(@beradadalam) example with _berada dalam_ NP (IWaC via Sketch Engine:ID77725)
(@berteduhdalam) example with _berteduh dalam_ NP (Antara News via WebCorp:11)
(@beradapada) example with _berada pada_ NP (ind_web2012_1M:642581)

While being happy is conceptualised as being at a location, being unhappy is conceptualised as being away from the `r scaps("happiness")`>-location (`r filter(location_submappings, str_detect(submappings, "being far from"))[["perc"]]`% of the metaphor's token) (@jauhdari)

(@jauhdari) example with _jauh dari_ (ind_newscrawl2012_1M:26855)

Other submappings built around `r scaps("happiness is a location")` are related to the change of location as expressed via motion verbs [cf. @dodge_deep_2016, pp. 274-275]. In the `r scaps('motion')`-related submappings, the Experiencer fills the Mover role and the `r scaps("happiness")` nouns fill the Location-related role, namely Source-location or Goal-location. The Mover can move *(in)to* ((@masukkedalam) and (@terjerumus)) or *away from* the Location ((@tinggalkan) to (@jauhkan)). These two change-of-location inferences are mapped onto the change-of-state aspect in the target, resulting in two other submappings. Namely, `r scaps("becoming happy is motion to a location")` (`r filter(location_submappings, str_detect(submappings, "motion into"))[["perc"]]`%) and `r scaps("ceasing happiness is moving away from the location")` (`r filter(location_submappings, str_detect(submappings, "moving away"))[["perc"]]`%). 

(@tinggalkan) example with _meninggalkan_ (ind_mixed2012_1M:950273)
(@hindari) example with _menghindari_ (ind_news2012_300K:116280)
(@jauhi) example with _menjauhi_ (ind_mixed2012_1M:25946)
(@jauhkan) example with _menjauhkan_ (ind_web2012_1M:825998)
(@masukkedalam) example with _masuk ke dalam_ (ind_mixed2012_1M:669544)
(@terjerumus) example with _terjerumus dalam_ (ind_mixed2012_1M:294560)

An interesting example is the use of the downward motion verb *terjerumus* in (@terjerumus). The uncontrolled falling movement conveyed by *terjerumus* suggests some sort of negative harm for the Mover (e.g., harmed face). In the target frame, this construal indicates that experiencing *kesenangan* 'pleasure' can be a negative one. This construal could be motivated by the `r scaps("negative states are low location")` [@dancygier_computational_2017, p. 579].

Another submapping incorporates a causal structure into the `r scaps("motion")` frame, such that the motion of the Mover is caused by the Agent role of some kind. This scene represents the `r scaps("caused change of state is caused motion to a location")` submapping (`r filter(location_submappings, str_detect(submappings, "causing.*?caused motion to"))[["perc"]]`%). In the target frame, this suggests that there is certain cause for someone's `r scaps("happiness")`. 

...

[Table \@ref(tab:lu-location)](#lu-location)^[The `top_n()` function of the *dplyr* package in R will include more rows from the specified 'n' number (i.e. ten) if there are ties among the group, i.e. the LUs, based on the variable used for ordering, i.e. their token frequency. Therefore, Table [\@ref(tab:lu-location)](#lu-location) specifically lists `r location_lu %>% dim() %>% .[1] %>% numbers2words` items when ten is requested.] shows that `r location_lu %>% filter(str_detect(Lexical_units, '^\\*dalam')) %>% .$Perc_overall`% of the tokens for `r scaps("happines is a location")` is due to one LU type, namely *dalam* 'inside sth.'. This proportion indicates that the metaphor is evoked by a conventional linguistic expression. This is further corroborated by the low percentage of variation in the metaphor's linguistic realisation given the metaphor's token frequency, that is, only `r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles('is a location', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor)[[2]]`% of the metaphor's overall tokens are expressed with different LU types.

```{r location-lu-table}
# print the LU
location_lu %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a location</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

In sum, `r scaps("happiness is a location")` metaphor principally foregrounds the nature of how one experiences `r scaps("happiness")`. This is reflected through the highest proportion of the `r scaps("being happy is being at a location")` submapping (`r sum(filter(location_submappings, str_detect(aspect, "being in a state"))[["perc"]])`%). The metaphor also highlights the change of state *away from* or *into* `r scaps("happiness")`; the former has higher proportion than the latter (`r sum(filter(location_submappings, str_detect(aspect, "state out"))[["perc"]])`% vs. `r sum(filter(location_submappings, str_detect(aspect, "state (in)?to"))[["perc"]])`%).

## Happiness is a located object {#locatedobject}

```{r located-object-data-for-maintext}
# submappings
located_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("located object$", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# lexical unit table
located_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("located object$", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# print the lu
located_lu %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a located object</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

The first one is the `r scaps("existence of happiness is presence of an object at a location")`, accounting for `r located_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, '^exis.*?presence')) %>% .$perc`% of the total tokens of the metaphor.

...

The first submapping entails the second one, i.e. `r scaps("inexistence of happiness is absence of an object at a location")`, representing `r located_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'absence')) %>% .$perc`% of the total tokens

...

The second submapping has its causative variant, namely `r scaps("causing happiness to cease is causing an object to be absent")` (`r located_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'vanishing')) %>% .$perc`%). This third submapping introduces the Agentive role to the scene via transitivising the LU, such as *hilang* 'be gone', using causative suffix -*kan*, into *hilang-kan* 'cause sth. to be gone'.

...

Despite its high token frequency, the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">located object</span> metaphor is less diverse in its linguistic manifestation due to nearly half of its total tokens (`r filter(located_lu, Perc_overall == max(Perc_overall))[["Perc_overall"]]`%) being evoked by *ada (di/pada X)* (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:lu-located-object)](#lu-located-object)). That is, the metaphor's frequent occurrence is composed of a proportionally limited type of LUs that are frequently repeated, rather than of a proportionally heterogeneous set of LUs [@gola_taste_2016, p. 53]. Overall, only `r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles(metaphor = "located object", type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor)[[2]]`% of the metaphor's tokens are of different LU types;  the rest of the tokens is repetition from that proportion [cf. @stefanowitsch_corpus_2017, p. 282].


## Happiness is a contained entity

```{r contained-entity-data-for-maintext}
# CONTAINED ENTITY metaphor data
## frames
contained_entity_frames <- happyr::get_frames(metaphor = "contained entity",
                                              df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>%
  group_by(frames) %>%
  summarise(n = sum(n)) %>%
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2),
         metaphors = "contained entity") %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

## submappings
contained_entity_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("contained entity",
                                                        df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "expression"), "expression", "containment"),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "(high intensity|intensified|intense)"), "increased intensity", aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "regulating"), "regulation", aspect))

## aspect summarised
contained_entity_aspect <- contained_entity_submappings %>% 
  group_by(aspect) %>% 
  summarise(n = sum(n), 
            type = sum(type), 
            perc = sum(perc), 
            type_perc = sum(type_perc)) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

## lexical unit table
contained_entity_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("contained entity",
                                            top_n_only = FALSE,
                                            df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

contained_entity_lu %>%
  top_n(10, N) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a contained entity</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

The submappings in the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">contained entity</span> metaphor involve `r numbers2words(dim(contained_entity_frames)[1])` source frames: (i) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">containing</span> (`r contained_entity_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'containing')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), (ii) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">being in a bounded region region</span> (`r contained_entity_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'bounded region')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), (iii) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">explosion</span> (`r contained_entity_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'explosion')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), (iv) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fragmentation scenario</span>^[The <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">explosion</span> and <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fragmentation scenario</span> frames are taken from the *FrameNet* repository; the rest are represented in the *MetaNet* repository.] (`r contained_entity_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'fragmentation')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), and (v) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">pressure in a container</span> (`r contained_entity_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'pressure')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%).

...

The most frequent submapping within the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">contained entity</span> metaphor (i.e. `r dplyr::filter(contained_entity_submappings, stringr::str_detect(submappings, "fullness"))[["perc"]]`% of the total `r tally(contained_entity_frames, n)[[1]] ` tokens of the metaphor) exploits the Fullness_degree role of the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">containing</span> frame. In other words, most of the lexical units (LUs) refer to the fullness of the Content inside the Container; in the target domain (TD), fullness of the contained entity is mapped onto the high extent of <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">happiness</span>.

...

The second predominant submapping is evoked by LUs referring to the 'containment' scene (`r dplyr::filter(contained_entity_submappings, stringr::str_detect(submappings, "a contained entity$"))[["perc"]]`%). This is mapped onto the experience/existence of <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">happiness</span> itself.

...

The Fullness of the Content may produce (i) pressure on the Container (`r dplyr::filter(contained_entity_submappings, stringr::str_detect(submappings, "pressing"))[["perc"]]`%) that, when it is uncontrollable, may result in (ii) explosion/breaking out of the Container (`r dplyr::filter(contained_entity_submappings, stringr::str_detect(submappings, "exploding"))[["perc"]]`%). The explosion-related submapping is made up of the <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">explosion</span> and <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">fragmentation scenario</span> frames.

...

Table XXX shows that `r filter(contained_entity_lu, Perc_overall == max(Perc_overall))[[4]]`% of the tokens of <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>happiness is a contained entity</span> metaphor is due to one LU, i.e. *penuh* 'to be full'. This points to a highly-conventionalised property of the metaphor in its linguistic manifestation, given the high frequency of a single LU compared to the others [cf. @gola_taste_2016, p. 53]. In other words, the relative entrenchment of the metaphor arises from a conventionalised expression, such as *penuh* 'to be full'. This is further supported by the metaphor's low percentage of the variation for its linguistic realisations (i.e., `r filter(ttr_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "contained entity"))[["type_per_token_lu"]]`%) over its overall token frequency.

## Happiness is a liquid in a container

```{r liquid-containment-data-for-maintext}
# LIQUID IN A CONTAINER metaphor data
## frames
contained_liquid_frames <- happyr::get_frames("liquid in a container", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(metaphors = 'liquid in a container') %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

## submappings
contained_liquid_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("liquid in a container", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "expression"), "expression", "containment"),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "(high intensity|intensified|intense)"), "increased intensity", aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "preventing"), "regulation", aspect),
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "accommodating"), "accommodating", aspect))

## aspect summarised
contained_liquid_aspect <- contained_liquid_submappings %>% 
  group_by(aspect) %>% 
  summarise(n = sum(n), 
            type = sum(type), 
            perc = sum(perc), 
            type_perc = sum(type_perc)) %>%
  arrange(desc(n))

## lexical unit table
contained_liquid_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("liquid in a container",
                                            top_n_only = FALSE,
                                            df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

contained_liquid_lu %>%
  top_n(10, N) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'The most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a liquid in a container</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```


The submappings within <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a liquid in a container</span> metaphor make use of structures from `r dim(contained_liquid_frames)[1] %>% happyr::numbers2words()` source frames that reflect a range of experiential knowledge concerning the behaviour of a contained liquid. They are (i) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">release liquid</span> (`r contained_liquid_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'release')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), (ii) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">heating fluid</span> (`r contained_liquid_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'heating')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), (iii) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fluid containment</span> (`r contained_liquid_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'fluid containment')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), (iv) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fluid motion</span> (`r contained_liquid_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'fluid motion')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%), and (v) <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">stop flow of substance</span> (`r contained_liquid_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'stop flow')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%). These frames are represented in the *MetaNet* frame repository.

To begin with, the existence of <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">happiness</span> is conceptualised as (i) liquid containment (`r contained_liquid_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'a liquid in a')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%)^[The percentage of liquid containment submapping does not correspond to the overall percentage of the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fluid containment</span> frame because the other portion of the metaphorical expressions evoking <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fluid containment</span> do not profile the liquid containment *per se*, but also include highlighting the Fluid_level role of the frame. I consider the expressions profiling the Fluid_level role of the frame to evoke a separate submapping, viz. indicating the Fullness of the contained fluid. See the discussion on citation XXX below.] and (ii) fluidic motion of the liquid (`r contained_liquid_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'is a fluidic motion$')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%). As to the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fludic motion</span> submapping, there are two scenarios attested in my sample. First, the liquid may flow inwardly from some source and throughout the body.

...

Next, there are two submappings that focus on the intense experience of <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">happiness</span>. The first submapping is based on the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">heated fluid</span> frame, namely <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">intensified happiness is heated liquid</span> (`r contained_liquid_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'heated liquid')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%)).

...

The second submapping is postulated via the profiling of the fullness of the Fluid_level role in the <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">fluid containment</span> frame, namely <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">intense happiness is brimming liquid in a container</span> (`r contained_liquid_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'fullness')) %>% select(perc) %>% unlist()`%).

...

<span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">Release liquid</span> is the most frequently evoked frame in the metaphor (i.e., `r filter(contained_liquid_frames, str_detect(frames, "release"))[["n"]]` tokens) and it has the highest number of LU types compared to the other frames in the metaphor (i.e., `r filter(contained_liquid_frames, str_detect(frames, "release"))[["type"]]` types).

...

Moreover, among the ten most frequent metaphors discussed in this chapter, `r scaps("happiness is a liquid in a container")` is the most diverse linguistically: `r filter(ttr_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "liquid in a container"))[["type_per_token_lu"]]`% of its tokens are of different LU types.


## Intensity of happiness is quantity of object

```{r quantity-data-for-maintext}
## submappings
quantity_submapping <- happyr::get_submappings("quantity of object",
                                               df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

## LU and submappings
quantity_focus_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("quantity of object",
                                          submapping_perc = TRUE,
                                          incl_submappings = TRUE,
                                          df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(mapping = if_else(str_detect(Submappings, 'more|adding'), 'more', 'less')) %>%
  group_by(mapping) %>%
  mutate(N_by_mapping = sum(N)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%

## aspect

  mutate(mapping = if_else(str_detect(submappings, 'more|adding'), 'more', 'less')) %>%
```

Overall, `r filter(quantity_focus, mapping == "more")[["perc"]]`% of the total `r tally(quantity_focus, n)[[1]]` tokens of the metaphorical expressions profile the 'more quantity' end of the entire <span style="font-variant:small-caps;">quantity</span> frame.

...

From the linguistic realisation point of view, the `r scaps('quantity')` metaphor can also be considered less diverse. Only `r filter(ttr_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "quantity of object"))[["type_per_token_lu"]]`% out of its `r tally(quantity_focus, n)[[1]]` tokens are expressed by different LU types. Among the predominant LUs include *tambahkan* 'to add sth.', *banyak* 'many/much', and *berlebihan* 'excessive'.

## Happiness is an (un)veiled object

```{r unveiled-object-data-for-maintext}
# frames
concealed_frames <- happyr::get_frames("veiled", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# submapping
concealed_submapping <- happyr::get_submappings("veiled", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# tokens concerning hiding and abilitative modal
hiding_tokens <- 1:filter(concealed_submapping, str_detect(submappings, "regulating"))[["n"]]
tokens_without_abilitative <- c(3, 10, 19, 21)
tokens_with_abilitative <- setdiff(hiding_tokens, tokens_without_abilitative)
tokens_with_abilitative_positive <- 15
tokens_with_abilitative_negated <- setdiff(tokens_with_abilitative, tokens_with_abilitative_positive)
tokens_without_abilitative_negated <- c(10, 21)

# lexical unit
concealed_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("veiled", top_n_only = TRUE, df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)
concealed_lu %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is an (un)veiled object</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

These two aspects are captured via three submappings. The most frequent one is the `r scaps('existence of happiness is visibility of an object')` (`r filter(concealed_submapping, str_detect(submappings, "visibility"))[["perc"]]`%), based on the <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>seeing</span> frame

...

The second submapping is based on the `r scaps('cause to see')` frame, namely `r scaps('expressing happiness is showing an object')` (`r filter(concealed_submapping, str_detect(submappings, "showing"))[["perc"]]`%).

...

The third submapping is `r scaps('regulating happiness is hiding an object')` (`r filter(concealed_submapping, str_detect(submappings, "hiding"))[["perc"]]`%). This mapping is expressed by lexical units (LUs) from the `r scaps('visual obstruction')` frame. In `r numbers2words(length(tokens_with_abilitative))` tokens of the total `r filter(concealed_submapping, str_detect(submappings, "regulating"))[["n"]]` citations of this submapping, the LUs co-occur with abilitative modal auxiliaries (i.e. *dapat/bisa* 'can', *mampu/sanggup* 'be able to'). Yet, `r numbers2words(length(tokens_with_abilitative_negated))` of these `r numbers2words(length(tokens_with_abilitative))` tokens are negated. Overall, including tokens without the abilitative modals, `r round((length(tokens_without_abilitative_negated) + length(tokens_with_abilitative_negated))/length(hiding_tokens) * 100, 2)`% citations of the `r scaps('regulating happiness is hiding an object')` are negated. This points to the focus on the *inability* to *conceal* the emotion.

...

Linguistically, `r scaps("happiness is an (un)veiled object")` metaphor also has a low percentage of variation for the evoking LUs (`r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles('veiled', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor)[[2]]`%). It is predominantly evoked by *lihat* 'to see/look at', *terlihat*, 'to be visible', *(t/n)ampak* 'to be visible', and *tunjukkan* 'to show'

## Happiness is a submerged entity

```{r submerged-entity-data-for-maintext}
## submappings
submerged_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings("submerged", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

## lexical unit table
submerged_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("submerged", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)
submerged_lu %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Top-10 most frequent lexical units evoking the <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is a submerged entity</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

Linguistically, the metaphor is proportionally less varied in its lexical realisation (`r happyr::get_meta_freq_profiles('submerged', type_per_token_lu, df = ttr_metaphor)[[2]]`% of lexical variation), given its token frequency. The high token frequency of the metaphor is accounted for mostly by the first three LUs in [Table \@ref(tab:lu-submerged-entity)](#lu-submerged-entity), taking up `r sum(happyr::get_cic_meta_lu("submerged", ttr_metaphor)[["Perc_overall"]])`% of the metaphor's token frequency.

...

In general, all the metaphorical expressions of <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>happiness is a submerged entity</span> indicate the manner through which <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>happiness</span> may exist. Namely, existence of <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>happiness</span> is understood as a surfacing or outward motion of an Entity, be it (i) naturally emerging (`r filter(submerged_submappings, !str_detect(submappings, 'cause'))[["perc"]]`%) or (ii) caused to emerge by some agent (`r filter(submerged_submappings, str_detect(submappings, 'cause'))[["perc"]]`%).


## Happiness is food

```{r food-data-for-maintext}
## submappings
food_submappings <- happyr::get_submappings('food', df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# frames
food_frames <- happyr::get_frames("food", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# frames and submappings
food_frames_submappings <- happyr::phd_data_metaphor %>% 
  filter(metaphors == 'happiness is food') %>% 
  count(source_frames, submappings) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  group_by(source_frames) %>% 
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2)) %>%

  ungroup()

## LU table
happyr::get_lu_table("food", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'All lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is food</span>.', row.names = TRUE)
```

<span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>Happiness is food</span> metaphor is based on several frames related to gastronomical experience. These include the <span style='font-variant:small-caps'>food</span> frame itself (`r food_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'food$')) %>% .$perc`%), <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>ingestion</span> (`r food_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'ingestion')) %>% .$perc`%), <span style='font-variant:small-caps'>food preparation</span>^[The entry for <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>food preparation</span> frame is not represented in the *MetaNet* frame repository, but is included as the source frame label for a metaphorical entailment of the <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>ideas are foods</span> metaphor, i.e. <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>preparing ideas to be understood is food preparation</span> (cf. https://metaphor.icsi.berkeley.edu/pub/en/index.php/Metaphor:PREPARING_IDEAS_TO_BE_UNDERSTOOD_IS_FOOD_PREPARATION). A related frame whose entry is available in the *FrameNet* frame repository is <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>cooking_creation</span>.] (`r food_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'preparation')) %>% .$perc`%), and, most predominantly, <span style='font-variant:small-caps;'>taste</span> (`r food_frames %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'taste')) %>% .$perc`%).

...

Most of the lexical units (LUs) in this frame profiles the serving stage of the food preparation (`r food_frames_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'serving')) %>% .$perc`%)

...

This is indicated especially by a high proportion of one LU, namely *nikmati* 'to taste-while-enjoying', taking up `r food_lu_submappings %>% filter(str_detect(lu, "nikmati$")) %>% .$perc_expr_overall`% of all tokens of the metaphor.

### Happiness is an imperilled entity

```{r happiness-is-an-imperilled-entity-data}
# submappings
endangered_submapping <- happyr::get_submappings("imperilled", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(submappings = str_replace(submappings, "destroyed object", "harmed entity"))

# frames
endangered_frame <- happyr::get_frames("imperilled", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

# lexical units table
endangered_lu <- happyr::get_lu_table("imperilled", top_n_only = TRUE, df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

endangered_lu_hapax <- dim(filter(endangered_lu, N == 1L))[1]

endangered_lu %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = 'Lexical units evoking <span style = "font-variant:small-caps;">happiness is an imperilled entity</span>', row.names = TRUE)
```

The `r happyr::scaps("happiness is an imperilled entity")` makes use of elements from several frames that broadly belong to the `r happyr::scaps("harm")` frame family [cf. @dodge_deep_2016, pp. 282-286] (see also discussion in `r section` XXX below). These frames include `r happyr::scaps("destroying")` (`r endangered_frame %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'destroy')) %>% .$perc`%), `r happyr::scaps("protecting")` (`r endangered_frame %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'protecting')) %>% .$perc`%), `r happyr::scaps("danger")` (`r endangered_frame %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'danger')) %>% .$perc`%), `r happyr::scaps("rejuvenation")` (`r endangered_frame %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'rejuve')) %>% .$perc`%), and `r happyr::scaps("impact")` (`r endangered_frame %>% filter(str_detect(frames, 'impact')) %>% .$perc`%). These frames are available in the *MetaNet* frame repository, except for `r happyr::scaps("rejuvenation")` which is taken from the *FrameNet* repository.

...

Inference from the constituting frames contributes quite rich metaphorical construal related to the above main theme. The predominant submapping, namely `r happyr::scaps("negatively affecting happiness is harming an entity")` (`r endangered_submapping %>% filter(perc == max(perc)) %>% .$perc`%) makes use of the Harmful_effect_process role of the `r happyr::scaps("physical harm")` frame.

...

Further inference from this `r happyr::scaps("harm")` metaphor model is that the results of the harmful action can be a complete dysfunction or undesirable condition of the entity (e.g., being destroyed). This knowledge is carried over to the target domain to conceptualise the complete ceasing of `r happyr::scaps("happiness")`. Hence, `r endangered_submapping %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, '^end of')) %>% .[,1] %>% unlist() %>% unname() %>% happyr::scaps()` (`r endangered_submapping %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, 'end of')) %>% .$perc`%) submapping.

...

The twists of these negative consequences may include two scenarios that can be recast as two submappings. The first is `r happyr::scaps("maintaining happiness is protecting an asset")` (`r endangered_submapping %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, '^maintain')) %>% .$perc`%); the second is `r happyr::scaps("restoring happiness is repairing a harmed entity")` (`r endangered_submapping %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, '^restoring')) %>% .$perc`%). These scenarios suggest the importance for the experiencer to look after and maintain h(is/er) well-being.

...

Most of the LUs for `r happyr::scaps("happiness is an imperilled entity")` occur only once (`r round(endangered_lu_hapax/dim(endangered_lu)[1] * 100, 2)`% of the total `r dim(endangered_lu)[1]` LU types).

## Multiple distinctive collexeme analysis in action

```{r mdca-metaphor-synonyms}
# MDCA for metaphor * synonyms with concise output
mdca_res <- happyr::mdca(df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor, concise_output = TRUE)

# MDCA for metaphor * synonyms with full output (i.e., include exp_probability, synonyms frequency); this is for the purpose of illustrating the MDCA in the chapter
mdca_res_full <- happyr::mdca(df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor, concise_output = FALSE)

# gloss table for synonyms
syn_gloss <- tribble(~synonyms, ~gloss, ~form, ~source,
                     "riang", "very happy, joyous, glad", "root", "S&ST.2004.p.830",
                     "gembira", "excited, enthusiastic, exuberant, ...", "root", "S&ST.2004.p.311",
                     "ceria", "pure, clean, clear; cheerful", "root", "S&ST.2004.p.198",
                     "bahagia", "(peaceful and) happy; happiness; luck(y), good fortune; welfare", "root", "S&ST.2004.p.75",
                     "senang", "happy, to feel well, contented, satisfied", "root","S&ST.2004.p.909",
                     "keriangan", "cheer(fulness), happiness, joy", "nominalised", "S&ST.2004.p.830",
                     "keceriaan", "purity; cheerfulness", "nominalised","S&ST.2004.p.198",
                     "kebahagiaan", "happiness, prosperity and contentment", "nominalised","S&ST.2004.p.75",
                     "kegembiraan", "joy, cheerfulness, high spirits", "nominalised","S&ST.2004.p.311",
                     "kesenangan", "pleasure, happiness, enjoyment, ...", "nominalised", "S&ST.2004.p.909") %>%
```
