```{r mdca-collocates-synonyms}
# mdca for window-span collocational data
mdca_colloc <- happyr::mdca(df = happyr::colloc_input_data, coll_var = "collocates")
```

```{r illustration-data-for-mdca}
# retrieve the example table
example_df <- mdca_res %>% 
  filter(str_detect(metaphors, "desired")) %>% 
  select(-metaphors) %>% 
  arrange(desc(assocstr))

# count the freq of the metaphors
metaphor_token <- dplyr::count(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, metaphors, sort = TRUE)

# count the freq of the synonyms
synonym_token <- dplyr::count(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, synonyms, sort = TRUE)

# input data
input_snippet <- mdca_res_full %>% 
  filter(str_detect(metaphors, "desired")) %>% 
  select(synonyms, n, cxn_sum) %>% 
  mutate(others = cxn_sum - n) %>% 
  select(synonyms, n, others, total = cxn_sum)

input_snippet <- input_snippet %>%
  bind_rows(input_snippet %>% 
              summarise_if(is.numeric, sum) %>% 
              mutate(synonyms = "total") %>% 
              select(synonyms, everything()))

# tokens for the examples in the text
obs_bhg <- filter(example_df, synonyms == "kebahagiaan")[["n"]]
sum_bhg <- filter(synonym_token, synonyms == "kebahagiaan")[["n"]]
exp_bhg <- filter(example_df, synonyms == "kebahagiaan")[["exp"]]
meta_destination <- filter(metaphor_token, str_detect(metaphors, "desired goal"))[["n"]]
exp_prob <- exp_bhg/meta_destination
```

```{r example-data-print}
# print out the results for example with 'DESIRED GOAL/DESTINATION'
example_df %>%
  mutate(gloss = c("happiness", 
                   "pleasure", 
                   "(peaceful and) happy; happiness", 
                   "very happy, joyous", 
                   "cheerful; lit. pure, clean", 
                   "happy, to feel well, contented", 
                   "excited, enthusiastic", 
                   "cheer(fulness)", 
                   "purity; cheerfulness", 
                   "joy, cheerfulness"),
         synonyms = paste("*", synonyms, "*", sep = ""),
         exp = round(exp, 3L)) %>%
  select(synonyms, gloss, everything()) %>%
  as.data.frame() %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = '*Observed* frequency (`n`), *expected* frequency (`exp`), and *Association Strength* (`assocstr`) for <span style="font-variant:small-caps";>happiness is a desired goal/destination</span> across the synonyms.', row.names = TRUE)
```

The observed co-occurrence frequency between *kebahagiaan* and metaphorical patterns evoking the `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` is `r obs_bhg` tokens. In addition to this observed co-occurrence frequency, one also needs the *expected frequency* for the co-occurrence between `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` and *kebahagiaan* (column "exp" in [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print)). The expected frequency (for a metaphor and a synonym) represents the frequency that one would expect under the null-hypothesis that the proportion of the metaphor were equally distributed across all synonyms under study; in other words, the null-hypothesis states that there are no distributional differences for the metaphor with each synonym [cf. @levshina_how_2015, pp. 210-211]. The expected frequency for our example is arrived at by multiplying (i) the total frequency of *kebahagiaan* in the sample, i.e., `r sum_bhg`, with (ii) the total frequency of `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` occurring with any synonyms in the sample, i.e., `r meta_destination`, then (iii) dividing the results with the total metaphorical tokens in the sample, i.e., `r dim(happyr::phd_data_metaphor)[1]`; hence (`r sum_bhg``*``r meta_destination`)/`r dim(happyr::phd_data_metaphor)[1]` = `r exp_bhg`. 

Difference between the observed and expected frequencies allows us to determine the direction of the association between the co-occurring items. The association can be (i) *positive*, if the observed frequency exceeds the expected frequency, or (ii) *negative*, if the observed frequency is below the expected frequency. The comparison between the expected and the observed frequency in [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print) for `r scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` with *kebahagiaan* indicates positive association, or *attraction*, between the metaphor and the synonym since the observed frequency of `r obs_bhg` is higher than the expected frequency of `r exp_bhg` [cf. @hilpert_distinctive_2006, p. 247]. Additional value required by the Binomial Test in MDCA is the *a priori* probability that if *kebahagiaan* is used metaphorically it will occur in metaphorical patterns evoking `r scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')`. This probability is calculated by dividing (i) the expected frequency of *kebahagiaan* with the metaphor (i.e., `r exp_bhg`) against (ii) the total frequency of the metaphor in the sample (i.e., `r meta_destination`), hence (`r exp_bhg`/`r meta_destination`) equals `r exp_prob` [@hilpert_distinctive_2006, p. 247].

The observed co-occurrence frequency, the total frequency of the metaphor, and the *a priori* probability then become the inputs for the one-tailed Binomial Test implemented in MDCA. Given our example, the Binomial Test will determine the Binomial *p*-value indicating the probability that the observed co-occurrence frequency of `r obs_bhg`, or even more often, for *kebahagiaan* and `r scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` would have come about by chance, given the null-hypothesis of equal distribution for a metaphor with all synonyms. The code-chunk below shows the R code to perform one-tailed Binomial Test for our example:

```{r binom-test-example, echo = TRUE}
# For one-tailed test, the *alternative* argument in the code is set to 'greater' 
# when the co-occ.freq is higher than expected; it set to "less" when otherwise.

binom.test(x = 125, # co-occ.freq between "kebahagiaan" and the "desired goal" metaphor
           n = 293, # total tokens of the "desired goal" metaphor
           p = 0.1882903, # a priori probability
           alternative = "greater" 
           )$p.value # retrieve only the binomial p-value
```

The resulting *p*~Binomial~-value here is small (i.e., `r binom.test(obs_bhg, meta_destination, exp_prob, 'greater')$p.value %>% format(scientific = TRUE)`)^[The alternative representation of this *p*-value is `r binom.test(obs_bhg, meta_destination, exp_prob, 'greater')$p.value %>% format(scientific = FALSE)`.]. This value indicates that there is a very low probability that we observe this co-occurrence distribution of `r obs_bhg` tokens, or even more, between *kebahagiaan* and `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` *if* there is *no*/*neutral* association between them. Similar calculation as above is done for the co-occurrence frequencies of each synonyms with the metaphors. The code-chunk below illustrates the computation of the *p*~Binomial~-value when the co-occurrence frequency is less than expected, as in between *kegembiraan* 'joy' and the `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` metaphor (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print)).

```{r binom-test-example-kegembiraan, echo = TRUE}
binom.test(x = 6, # co-occ.freq between "kegembiraan" and the "desired goal" metaphor
           n = 293, # total tokens of the "desired goal" metaphor
           p = 0.184442, # a priori probability
           alternative = "less" 
           )$p.value # retrieve only the binomial p-value
```

As in most Collostructional Analysis studies, the *p*-values of the Binomial Test in this case are used directly as the measure for association strength. The small *p*~Binomial~-value and the positive deviation of the observed frequency from the expected one for our example with *kebahagiaan* 'happiness' indicates significantly high degree of association (viz. *attraction*) between *kebahagiaan* and `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')`. For expository reason, Collostructional Analysis log~10~-transforms the *p*~Binomial~-value into the so-called *Coll(ostruction) Str(ength)* value; in this thesis, it is referred to as the *Assoc(iation) Str(ength)* value (cf. the `"assocstr"` column in [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print)) [@stefanowitsch_covarying_2005, p. 7]. Positive or negative signs are set in the *AssocStr* values to indicate the direction of association. Positive *AssocStr* values indicate *attraction* (i.e., the observed co-occurrence frequency is higher than the expected frequency); it is derived from the *negative* log~10~-transformed *p*~Binomial~-value, as shown below for the *kebahagiaan* 'happiness' example.

```{r log10-kebahagiaan, echo = TRUE}
# get the p-value of the Binomial Test
p_binomial <- binom.test(x = 125, n = 293, p = 0.1882903, alternative = "greater")$p.value

# negative log10 for the p-binom for the *kebahagiaan* data
-log10(x = p_binomial)
```

Meanwhile, negative *AssocStr* values indicate *repulsion* (i.e., the observed co-occurrence frequency is less than expected); it is derived from the *positive* log~10~-transformed *p*~Binomial~-value, as shown below for the *kegembiraan* 'joy' example.

```{r log10-kegembiraan, echo = TRUE}
# get the p-value of the Binomial Test
p_binomial <- binom.test(x = 6, n = 293, p = 0.184442, alternative = "less")$p.value

# positive log10 for the p-binom for the *kegembiraan* data
log10(x = p_binomial)
```


One can notice from [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print) that `r scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` is also significantly distinctive to *kesenangan* 'pleasure', though in a lower degree compared to *kebahagiaan*, as reflected in the AssocStr values between the two; qualitatively, it will be shown that *kesenangan* and *kebahagiaan* differ in relation to the preferred submappings of the `r scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` (cf. `r section`[\@ref(bahagia)](#bahagia) and `r section`[\@ref(senang)](#senang)). This kind of multiple association of an item (i.e., a metaphor) to more than one construction of interest (i.e., the synonyms) is not uncommon in MDCA, as Gilquin [-@gilquin_corpus_2010, p. 201, Table 60] has shown in her study of ten periphrastic causative constructions in English. Yet, the AssocStr values of the shared, attracted item with the constructions can be used to assume the relative association strength of the item with the constructions.

In Collostructional Analysis, the commonly used cut-off points in indicating significant association strength is AssocStr > 1.30103, which is equal to *p*~Binomial~ < 0.05 [@stefanowitsch_covarying_2005, p. 7]. Higher cut-off points can also be used: (i) AssocStr > 2, which is equal to *p*~Binomial~ < 0.01, and (ii) AssocStr > 3, which is equal to *p*~Binomial~ < 0.001. These AssocStr threshold values will be marked with negative sign when the co-occurrence frequencies are less than expected. For each synonym, the AssocStr values of the metaphors can be sorted from the highest (positive) to the lowest (down to the negative values). This will rank the metaphors from the most distinctive ones to the most strongly repelled. [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print) illustrates that significant repulsion for the metaphor according to the cut-off points can be seen from row number five. That is, starting from *`r example_df %>% filter(assocstr < -1.30103) %>% .[1,] %>% .$synonyms`* 'cheerful' (AssocStr = `r example_df %>% filter(assocstr < -1.30103) %>% .[1,] %>% .$assocstr`) down to *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness' (AssocStr = `r example_df %>% filter(assocstr < -1.30103, str_detect(synonyms, '^keceria')) %>% .$assocstr`) and *kegembiraan* 'joy, cheerfulness' (AssocStr = `r example_df %>% filter(assocstr < -1.30103, str_detect(synonyms, '^kegembira')) %>% .$assocstr`), the two synonyms showing the strongest dissociation with `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` metaphor.

The AssocStr-based ranked-list of the metaphors for each synonym is a starting point for qualitative discussion concerning the way semantically similar emotion concepts are characterised by, and vary in terms of, certain distinctive and repelled metaphors. In other words, a set of metaphors are strongly distinctive for an emotion compared to its synonyms presumably because these metaphors map conceptual knowledge that best characterises the semantic foci of the emotion. The repelled metaphors may then indicate the less entrenched metaphorical model in conceptualising the given emotion. 

In relation to the aim of this chapter, the example in [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print) minimally confirms Kövecses' assumption regarding the existence of principal, or *distinctive*, metaphors distinguishing near-synonyms of emotions. After all, it is a basic assumption in Cognitive Linguistics, in relation to its usage-based tenet [@evans_cognitive_2006, p. 122], that different usage forms (e.g. metaphorical patterns) of a linguistic unit (e.g. an emotion lexeme), have impacts on its meaning (e.g. its metaphorical construal). Nevertheless, given such quantitative method as MDCA, this usage-based assumption can be fleshed out, and the way a set of emotion synonyms differ in their preferred metaphorical conceptualisations can be spelled out more explicitly. 

Note that MDCA, and the other members of Collostructional Analysis, involves repeated significance testing on the same data set [@stefanowitsch_covarying_2005, p. 36, endnote 3; @stefanowitsch_corpora_2009, p. 944]. As a rule-of-thumb, the standard threshold for the significance level, that is *p*~Binomial~ < 0.05, should be corrected for such repeated significance testing, using either the Bonferroni or Holm's correction methods^[These correction methods are available in *R* via the `p.adjust()` built-in function in the `{stats}` package. The `p.adjust()` function requires at least two input-arguments: (i) the numeric vector of *p*-values from each significance testing, and (ii) the names of the correction methods to be used, e.g. "bonferroni" or "holm". See the following website for examples: http://rcompanion.org/rcompanion/f_01.html.] [@gries_statistics_2009, pp. 242-243]. The correction is meant to restrict the significance threshold for repeated tests since there can be more chances for "a seemingly significant result has come about by accident" when more significance tests are performed [@stefanowitsch_cognitive_2011, p. 275, footnote 5]. Consequently, only certain items, whose original *p*~Binomial~-values are below the corrected significance threshold, if any, will be strictly considered significant. However, most Collostructional Analysis studies are relaxed regarding such correction. The main reason is that it is the AssocStr-based *ranking* of the collexemes (or, in our case, the metaphors) that is the most relevant for the Collostructional Analysis, rather than the strict corrected significance level [@stefanowitsch_covarying_2005, p. 36, endnote 3; @stefanowitsch_function_2005, p. 178; @stefanowitsch_corpora_2009, p. 944]. Another reason is the tradition in corpus linguistics that considers each significance test as an independence test [@stefanowitsch_corpora_2009, p. 944]. Similar practice is also adopted in the *Semantic Profile* study by Janda & Lyashevskaya [-@janda_semantic_2013], in which there is no mention of a correction method used for the *p*~FisherYatesExact~-values in the paper.

In this chapter, following Stefanowitsch [-@stefanowitsch_cognitive_2011, p. 282], I report the distinctive and repelled metaphors for each synonym that are *both* significant at the uncorrected significance level, based on their AssocStr values, *and* at the corrected one, using the Holm method [@gries_statistics_2009, p. 249]. The reason for this report structure is that, as Stefanowitsch [-@stefanowitsch_function_2005, p. 178] has shown, collexemes/items that are identified as only *marginally*, or even *not*, significant, given a certain significance threshold, may also reveal systematic differences between the contrasted construction. That is amongst the reasons for the primary importance of the *ranking* in Collostructional Analysis. In [Table \@ref(tab:example-data-print)](#example-data-print) above, the column "p.holm" shows the corrected *p*~Binomial~-values with the Holm method. The "dec" column indicates the significance threshold of the corrected *p*~Holm~-values: `***` = *p*~Holm~ < 0.001; `**` = *p*~Holm~ < 0.01; `*` = *p*~Holm~ < 0.05; `ms` = marginally significant at *p*~Holm~ > 0.05; and `ns` = not significant at *p*~Holm~ > 1. For the AssocStr limit, I present the metaphors with the AssocStr > 2 (for attraction) and AssocStr < -2 (for repulsion).

```{r kebahagiaan-data-maintext}
## submappings for POSSESSABLE OBJECT for KEBAHAGIAAN----
# get submapping of POSSESSABLE OBJECT
kbhg_submet_possess <- happyr::get_submappings("possessable", "bahagiaan", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)  %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "(giving|dispersing|offering|caused motion)"), "cause", "others"), 
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "gaining"), "gaining", aspect), 
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "possessing"), "possessing", aspect), 
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "(losing|seized)"), "ceasing/losing", aspect))

# get submapping of 'cause' aspect
kbhg_asp_cause <- kbhg_submet_possess %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "giving|caused motion|dispersing|offering"))

# get submapping of 'attainment' aspect
kbhg_asp_gain <- kbhg_submet_possess %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "gaining"))

# get submapping of 'experience' aspect
kbhg_asp_possess <- kbhg_submet_possess %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "possessing"))

# get submapping of 'losing' aspect
kbhg_asp_losing <- kbhg_submet_possess %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "losing|seized"))

## submappings for MOVING OBJECT for KEBAHAGIAAN----
```

From [Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-kebahagiaan)](#distinctive-for-kebahagiaan), the metaphor that is most distinctive for *kebahagiaan* 'happiness' (N~metaphorical~ = `r filter(synonym_token, synonyms == "kebahagiaan")[["n"]]`^[This value indicates the total tokens of metaphorical patterns for a synonym in the sample.] tokens), namely `r happyr::scaps('happiness is a desired goal/destination')` metaphor, suggests the aspirative nature of *kebahagiaan* 'happiness'.

...

From the total tokens of the `r scaps('desired goal/destination')` metaphor occuring with *kebahagiaan*, most of the metaphorical lexical units (LUs) focus of on the 'attainment' rather than on the other aspects, such as the 'pursuing'. The prominence of 'attainment' is reflected in both its token (`r kebahagiaan_propasp_attaintment`% of the metaphor's `r sum(kebahagiaan_submapping_destination$n)` tokens) and type frequencies (`r sum(kebahagiaan_aspect_attainment$type)` different LU types).

...

In my Indonesian sample, *kebahagiaan* proportionally more frequently occurs in metaphorical expressions denoting the 'transferring' of the possessable object (`r sum(kbhg_asp_cause$perc)`%), as in _**memberikan** (X) kebahagiaan_ 'to *give* (X) happiness' (based on the `r happyr::scaps('giving')` frame), _**membawa** kebahagiaan_ 'to *bring* happiness' (`r happyr::scaps('caused motion')` frame), and _**berbagi** kebahagiaan_ 'to *share* happiness' (`r happyr::scaps('dispersal')` frame), among the most frequent metaphorical patterns.

...

In contrast to *kebahagiaan*, the three most distinctive metaphors at the corrected significance level for its root, namely *bahagia* 'happy; happiness', broadly highlights the experience or feeling aspect of *bahagia* (N~metaphorical~ = `r filter(synonym_token, synonyms == "bahagia")[["n"]]`) (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-bahagia)](#distinctive-for-bahagia)).

Next, the results of MDCA for the (window-based) distinctive lexical co-occurrence, or collocates, of *kebahagiaan*^[I limit the scope for the collocation data to the nominalised forms of the `r happyr::scaps("happiness")` synonyms for two reasons. First, they are more frequent than their corresponding root-nominal forms. Second, they are exclusively used as nominals with inherent reference function. Meanwhile, the typical usages of the root forms are attributive and predicative, rather than nominal/reference function.] reveal further semantic nuances. They indicate what concepts (e.g. other emotions, attitudes, descriptions, or evaluations) are strongly associated with *kebahagiaan* in the corpus. Theoretically, the concepts evoked by the distinctive collocates can be an operationalisation for Kövecses' [-@kovecses_where_2015, p. 158] idea regarding *related concepts* for certain emotions [cf. @oster_using_2010, for similar uses of collocation data to reveal conceptual proximity and semantic prosody of an emotion.].

```{r colloc-res-kebahagiaan}

  select(-synonyms) %>%
  select(collocates, gloss, everything()) %>%
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3), 
         collocates = paste("*", collocates, "*", sep = "")) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption="The 20 most distinctive, 4-window span collocates for *kebahagiaan* 'happiness' in the whole Indonesian Leipzig Corpora collection.", row.names = TRUE)
```

## Distinctive metaphors for *kesenangan* 'pleasure; happiness' and *senang* 'happy; happiness; to feel well' {#senang}

```{r kesenangan-data-maintext}
# submapping for POSSESSABLE OBJECT for *kesenangan*----
ksng_submet_possess <- happyr::get_submappings(metaphor = "possessable", word = "kesenangan", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  mutate(aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "(giving|dispersing|offering|caused motion)"), "cause", "others"), 
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "gaining"), "gaining", aspect), 
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "possessing"), "possessing", aspect), 
         aspect = if_else(str_detect(submappings, "(losing|seized)"), "ceasing/losing", aspect))

# submapping for DESIRED OBJECT for *kesenangan*----
pursuing_perc <- happyr::get_submappings(metaphor = "desired goal", word = "kesenangan", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% 
  filter(str_detect(submappings, "pursuing|aiming")) %>% 
  tally(perc) %>% 
  unlist()

# total tokens of (UN)MIXED SUBSTANCE overall-----
mixed_substance_tokens <- dim(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "mixed")))[1]

## tokens indicating 'pure' substance
mixed_substance_pure_tokens <- dim(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "mixed"), str_detect(lu, "murni")))[1] 

## tokens indicating 'mixed' substance
mixed_substance_mixed_tokens <- mixed_substance_tokens - mixed_substance_pure_tokens
```

```{r distinctive-for-kesenangan}
mdca_res %>%
  happyr::mdca_attr(cxn_type = "kesenangan", min_assocstr = 2) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Distinctive metaphors for *kesenangan* 'pleasure; happiness'", row.names = TRUE)
```


The first point, as I have mentioned, is that `r happyr::scaps(tolower('HAPPINESS IS A DESIRED GOAL/DESTINATION'))` is also the most distinctive metaphor for _kesenangan_ 'pleasure' as it is for _kebahagiaan_ 'happiness', though the metaphor is most strongly associated with the latter according to its AssocStr values (`r filter(example_df, synonyms == "kesenangan")[["assocstr"]]` for *kesenangan* vs. `r filter(example_df, synonyms == "kebahagiaan")[["assocstr"]]` for *kebahagiaan*). Despite this similar attraction, a finer grained difference emerges between the two words in relation to the submappings of the metaphor. *Kesenangan* most frequently occurs with metaphorical patterns denoting the 'pursuing' aspect (`r pursuing_perc`% of all the tokens) rather than the 'attainment', which is more frequent for *kebahagiaan*.

...

`r happyr::get_frames(metaphor = "impediment to motion$", word = "kesenangan", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% filter(n == max(n)) %>% .$n %>% happyr::numbers2words()` out of `r happyr::get_frames(metaphor = "impediment to motion", word = "kesenangan", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor) %>% .$n %>% sum() %>% happyr::numbers2words()` tokens for the occurrence of this metaphor with *kesenangan* evoke the `r happyr::scaps("restraints")` frame. In this frame, *kesenangan* maps onto the Restraining_entity role (e.g. _**dikendalikan** oleh kesenangan_ 'to be *reined back* by pleasure', _kesenangan **mengendalikan/mengikat** X_ 'pleasure *reins back/binds* X', _**memikat** X **pada** kesenangan_ 'to *decoy/ensnare* X *at* pleasure'). In this case, the Experiencer comes under restraining control of *kesenangan* that makes him difficult to take other actions. 

...

For *kesenangan*, `r ksng_submet_possess %>% filter(aspect == "gaining") %>% .$perc %>% sum()`% of the usage tokens evoke the 'receiving' of the Possessable_object (i.e., the 'onset' of pleasure), which is based on the `r happyr::scaps("gain possession")` frame.

Now I turn to discuss the distinctive collocates for *kesenangan* 'pleasure' shown in [Table \@ref(tab:colloc-res-kesenangan)](#colloc-res-kesenangan).

```{r colloc-res-kesenangan}
# present the result table for collocational analysis for *kesenangan*
happyr::mdca_attr(mdca_colloc, cxn_type = '^kesenangan') %>% 
  top_n(20, assocstr) %>% 
  left_join(happyr::dist_colloc_gloss, by = "collocates") %>% # left-join the gloss for the distinctive collocates
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  select(collocates, gloss, everything()) %>%
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3), 
         collocates = paste("*", collocates, "*", sep = "")) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption="The 20 most distinctive, 4-window span collocates for *kesenangan* 'pleasure; happiness' in the whole Indonesian Leipzig Corpora collection.", row.names = TRUE)
```

Some of the distinctive collocates of *kesenangan* provide further support for arguing the negative contour assigned to *kesenangan*, as inferred from the distinctive metaphors. To begin with the most distinctive collocate, namely *duniawi* 'wordly; earthly', everything related to it is conceived as mundane and tends to be dispreferred over the divinity, incorporealism, or eternity, which is prescribed by certain religious view. Similar religious-based outlook then gives negavite association to the other 'mundane'-related collocates, such as *nafsu*^[The word *hawa* 'air' in [Table \@ref(tab:colloc-res-kesenangan)](#colloc-res-kesenangan) is part of an established compound in Indonesian with the word *nafsu* 'lust', that is *hawa nafsu* 'lust, lit. the air of the lust'. Thus, upon inspecting the full sentences of the `r happyr::numbers2words(filter(mdca_colloc, synonyms == "kesenangan", collocates == "hawa")[["n"]])` tokens for which *hawa* collocates with *kesenangan* within the span of four words to the left and right, there is only one occasion in which *hawa* does not collocate with *nafsu*, but appears alone indicating its homonymy with *hawa* meaning 'female' (the antonym for *Adam* 'male; lit. Adam', hence another common phrase *Kaum Adam dan Hawa* 'Male and Female group; lit Adam and Eve group').] 'lust', *seksual* 'sexual', *kebutuhan* 'needs', and *dosa* 'sin'. This is different from the positive nuances of *kebahagiaan* as conveyed by its distinctive collocates (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:colloc-res-kebahagiaan)](#colloc-res-kebahagiaan)). Another top collocate for *kesenangan* is *pribadi* 'personal; private', indicating the self-centred of *kesenangan* compared to *kebahagiaan*, which is more about wider audience (e.g. *orang* 'person', *manusia* 'human'). This 'personal/general-audience' feature will also be shown to be one of the semantic benchmarks distinguishing *kesenangan* 'pleasure' with the remaining `r happyr::scaps("happiness")` concepts.

## Distinctive metaphors for *kegembiraan* 'joy; cheerfulness' and *gembira* 'excite(d/ment); enthusias(tic/m)' {#gembira}

```{r kegembiraan-data-maintext}
# submapping for LIQUID IN A CONTAINER metaphor
kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer <- happyr::get_submappings(metaphor = "liquid in a container$", word = "kegembiraan", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

kgmb_prop_with_liquidincontainer <- mdca_res %>% 
  filter(str_detect(metaphors, "liquid in a container$")) %>% 
  select(1:3) %>% 
  # get the proportion of the LIQUID IN A CONTAINER metaphor across the synonyms
  mutate(perc = round(n/sum(n) * 100, 2)) %>%
  arrange(desc(perc))

# submapping for (UN)VEILED OBJECT metaphor
kgmb_unveiled_submet <- happyr::get_submappings(metaphor = "veiled", word = "(kegembiraan|^gembira)", df = happyr::phd_data_metaphor)

kgmb_unveiled_submet_max <- kgmb_unveiled_submet %>% 
  group_by(synonyms) %>% 
  filter(perc == max(perc)) %>%
  ungroup()

negated_sentences_for_hiding <- (9/10) * 100
```

[Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-kegembiraan)](#distinctive-for-kegembiraan) shows the distinctive metaphors for *kegembiraan* 'joy; cheerfulness'.

```{r distinctive-for-kegembiraan}

  happyr::mdca_attr(cxn_type = "kegembiraan", min_assocstr = 2) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Distinctive metaphors for *kegembiraan* 'joy; cheerfulness'", row.names = TRUE)
```


Two submappings are dominant. First, `r filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, perc == max(perc))[["perc"]]`% of the tokens consists of expressions evoking the `r happyr::scaps("release liquid")` frame, which is used to convey the expression of uncontrolled internal feeling, hence the submapping `r happyr::scaps(filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, str_detect(submappings, "released"))[["submappings"]])`. This submapping for *kegembiraan* is also the most productive in comparison to the others since it is expressed by `r happyr::numbers2words(filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, str_detect(submappings, "released"))[["type"]])` different lexical unit (LU) types (`r filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, str_detect(submappings, "released"))[["type_perc"]]`% of all types for the metaphor occurring with *kegembiraan*).

...

The second dominant submapping is `r happyr::scaps(filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, str_detect(submappings, "heated"))[["submappings"]])` (`r filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, str_detect(submappings, "heated"))[["perc"]]`%), which is based on the `r happyr::scaps("heated liquid")` frame. The most frequent metaphorical pattern is _**meluapkan** kegembiraan_ 'to *boil over* joy; lit. to *cause* joy to *boil over*'. Unlike the `r happyr::scaps("release liquid")` frame, the `r happyr::scaps("heated fluid")`-based submapping is only evoked by `r happyr::numbers2words(filter(kgmb_submet_liquidincontainer, str_detect(submappings, "heated"))[["type"]])` distinct LUs: *meluapkan* 'to cause to boil over' (a causative transitive verb) and *meluap(-luap)* 'to (keep) boil(ing) over' (an intransitive verb).  

...

The high frequency of these submappings, and more generally the distinctive association of `r happyr::scaps("liquid in a container")` with *kegembiraan*, informs the discussion in `r '**Chapter 5**'` that the prominence of the `r happyr::scaps("released liquid")` and `r happyr::scaps("heated liquid")` submappings for the whole `r happyr::scaps("happiness")` domain is contributed by the highest proportion of the metaphor to occur with *kegembiraan* (`r filter(kgmb_prop_with_liquidincontainer, synonyms == "kegembiraan")[["perc"]]`%) rather than with the remaining `r happyr::numbers2words(dim(filter(kgmb_prop_with_liquidincontainer, synonyms != "kegembiraan"))[1])` synonyms.

[Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-gembira)](#distinctive-for-gembira) presents the strongly distinctive metaphors for *gembira* 'excite(d/ment); enthusias(tic/m)', though non of them are significant at the corrected level.

Out of the three postulated submappings for `r happyr::scaps('happiness is an (un)veiled object')`, the dominant submapping for the nominalised (`r filter(kgmb_unveiled_submet_max, synonyms == "kegembiraan")[["perc"]]`% of the metaphor tokens) and root-nominal forms (`r filter(kgmb_unveiled_submet_max, synonyms == "gembira")[["perc"]]`%) is the same, namely `r happyr::scaps(unique(kgmb_unveiled_submet_max$submappings))` (e.g. *raut _gembira_ __tampak__ dari raut wajah Sri* 'whittle of excitement be *visible* from Sri's face'). From the total `r happyr::numbers2words(sum(filter(kgmb_unveiled_submet, str_detect(submappings, "hiding"))[["token"]]))` tokens of the submapping with the two words, all evoked by the verb *menyembunyikan* 'to hide', `r negated_sentences_for_hiding`% of the use of the verbal LUs are negated (e.g. *tidak* dapat _**menyembunyikan**_ *rasa gembira* 'can*not* *hide* X's feeling of excitement').


[Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-keceriaan)](#distinctive-for-keceriaan) shows the distinctive metaphors for *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness; lit. purity' (N~metaphorical~ = `r dplyr::filter(synonym_token, synonyms == "keceriaan")[["n"]]`). The root-nominal *ceria* 'cheerful; lit. pure, clean' (N~metaphorical~ = `r dplyr::filter(synonym_token, synonyms == "ceria")[["n"]]`) is absent since the AssocStr values of its distinctive metaphors do not reach 2.

```{r distinctive-for-keceriaan}
mdca_res %>%
  happyr::mdca_attr(cxn_type = "keceriaan", min_assocstr = 2) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Distinctive metaphors for *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness'", row.names = TRUE)
```

For the `r happyr::scaps("contained entity")` metaphor, `r filter(kcra_submet_contained, str_detect(submappings, "fullness"))[["perc"]]`% of the tokens consist of metaphorical patterns referring to the 'fullness' of the contained emotion-entity. The patterns are expressed by only `r numbers2words(filter(kcra_submet_contained, str_detect(submappings, "fullness"))[["type"]])` LU types, namely, *__penuh__ (dengan) keceriaan* 'to be *full* with/of cheerfulness' (`r filter(kcra_submet_contained_lu, lu == "penuh")[["n"]]` tokens), *keceriaan __memenuhi__ X* 'cheerfulness *fills* X *up*' (`r filter(kcra_submet_contained_lu, lu == "penuhi")[["n"]]` tokens), and *keceriaan __menyesaki__ X* 'X be *jam-packed* with cheerfulness; cheerfulness *fills* X *up*' (`r filter(kcra_submet_contained_lu, lu == "sesaki")[["n"]]` tokens). Only `r filter(kcra_submet_contained, str_detect(submappings, "exploding"))[["perc"]]`% of the metaphor's token indicates the 'exploding' container, suggesting the inability to held back the feeling, hence its expression (*keceriaan yang __meledak__* 'cheerfulness that *explodes*').

...

Related inference for intensity is indicated by the submappings of the less strongly attracted metaphor, namely `r happyr::scaps("intensity of happiness is quantity of object")`. The predominant submapping broadly indicates more quantity of object (`r sum(dplyr::filter(kcra_submet_quantity, str_detect(submappings, "(adding|more)"))[["perc"]])`% of the total tokens of the metaphor occurring with *keceriaan*). This further subsumes two events: (i) 'adding' the quantity of an object (`r kcra_submet_quantity %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "adding")) %>% .$perc`%), which could map onto the intensification process of *keceriaan*, and (ii) the state of an object in 'large quantity' (`r kcra_submet_quantity %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "more quantity")) %>% .$perc`%), which could map onto the 'intense' state of *keceriaan*. The second of these is expressed by `r kcra_submet_quantity %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "more quantity")) %>% .$type %>% happyr::numbers2words()` different lexical unit (LU) types compared to only `r kcra_submet_quantity %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "adding")) %>% .$type %>% happyr::numbers2words()` for the first (i.e., _**tambah(kan)** keceriaan_ 'to *add* cheerfulness'). The metaphorical patterns containing LUs indicating 'large quantity' include _**berjuta/seribu/banyak** keceriaan_ '*millions of/thousands of/many* cheerfulness', _keceriaan **menumpuk**_ 'cheerfulness *piles-up*', among others. The predominant submapping of `r happyr::scaps("quantity")` metaphor coheres with the 'fullness' submapping of the `r happyr::scaps("contained entity")` metaphor in conveying intensity, given the fullness of a content correlates with large amount of content in relation to the capacity of the holding container.

...

For the `r happyr::scaps("colour")` metaphor, the metaphorical patterns most frequently liken the experience of *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness' as being coloured (`r kcra_submet_colour %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "being coloured")) %>% .$perc`% of the total tokens). However, the metaphorical patterns are based on only `r kcra_submet_colour %>% filter(str_detect(submappings, "being coloured")) %>% .$type %>% happyr::numbers2words()` type of lexical unit

...

Similar 'visual' tone of *keceriaan* is argued to be conveyed via different image, namely the `r happyr::scaps("embellishment")` metaphor. Instead of being coloured, experience of *keceriaan* is conceptualised as being embellished. The most frequent metaphorical pattern (i.e., `r filter(count(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, str_detect(metaphors, "embellish")), m_expr, sort = TRUE), n == max(n))[["n"]] %>% happyr::numbers2words()` tokens) is *keceriaan __menghiasi__ X* 'cheerfulness *embellishes* X', with the "X" slot is predominantly filled with the noun *wajah* 'face'

...

Be that as it may, both *keceriaan* and *kegembiraan* also equally have strong attraction to the `r happyr::scaps("(un)veiled object")` metaphor (AssocStr = `r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "veiled"), synonyms == "keceriaan")[["assocstr"]]` for *keceriaan* and AssocStr = `r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "veiled"), synonyms == "kegembiraan")[["assocstr"]]` for *kegembiraan*), which also focuses on the idea of 'expressivity' and 'regulation' of the feeling, though it is not significance for the corrected level.

...

It should also be mentioned that there are two distinctive metaphors for the nominal root *ceria* 'cheerfulness' that are also distinctive for the nominalised form *keceriaan*, even though the attraction does not reach the corrected level of significance for *ceria* (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-ceria)](#distinctive-for-ceria)). These metaphors are `r happyr::scaps("happiness is a colour")` (N = `r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "colour$"), synonyms == "ceria")[["n"]]`, AssocStr = `r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "colour$"), synonyms == "ceria")[["assocstr"]]`, dec = *`r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "colour$"), synonyms == "ceria")[["dec"]]`*) and `r happyr::scaps("happiness is a contained entity")` (N = `r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "contained entity"), synonyms == "ceria")[["n"]]`, AssocStr = `r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "contained entity"), synonyms == "ceria")[["assocstr"]]`, dec = *`r filter(mdca_res, str_detect(metaphors, "contained entity"), synonyms == "ceria")[["dec"]]`*). This finding further indicates that, despite the lexical variation denoting the domain, there can be a tendency of similar usages and construal within the same general domain, as already been shown between the root and nominalised forms for `r happyr::scaps("gembira")` in `r section`[\@ref(gembira)](#gembira).

```{r distinctive-for-ceria}
mdca_res %>%
  happyr::mdca_attr(cxn_type = "^ceria$", min_assocstr = 1.30103) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Distinctive metaphors for *ceria* 'cheerful(ness)'", row.names = TRUE)
```

Looking at [Table \@ref(tab:repelled-by-keceriaan)](#repelled-by-keceriaan) for the repelled metaphors, *keceriaan* significantly repels the `r happyr::scaps("desired goal")` metaphor, distinguishing it from the distinctive metaphorical construal of *kebahagiaan* 'happiness' and *kesenangan* 'pleasure'.

```{r repelled-by-keceriaan}
mdca_res %>%
  happyr::mdca_repel(cxn_type = "keceriaan", min_assocstr = -2) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Repelled metaphors for *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness'", row.names = TRUE)
```

Similar repulsion to the `r happyr::scaps("desired goal")` metaphor is also shown by the root nominal *ceria* 'cheerful' (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:repelled-by-ceria)](#repelled-by-ceria)).

```{r repelled-by-ceria}
mdca_res %>%
  happyr::mdca_repel(cxn_type = "^ceria$", min_assocstr = -1.30103) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Repelled metaphor(s) for *ceria* 'cheerfulness'", row.names = TRUE)
```


The fact that *keceriaan* also repels `r happyr::scaps("object's dimension")` with 'intensity' interpretation does not undermine its association with other metaphors highlighting similar quality. It is argued that the intensity of *keceriaan* is captured using different form of metaphorical patterns that evoke certain semantic frame, such as `r happyr::scaps("object quantity")` that is distinctive for *keceriaan*, rather than patterns evoking `r happyr::scaps("object's dimension")` frame. This is reflected by the most frequent pattern indicating the concept of `r scaps("object quantity")`, that is _**menambah** keceriaan_ 'to *add* cheerfulness' (`r filter(count(filter(happyr::phd_data_metaphor, synonyms == "keceriaan", str_detect(metaphors, "quantity")), m_expr, sort = TRUE), n == max(n))[["n"]]` tokens), compared to the only `r happyr::numbers2words(filter(mdca_res, synonyms == "keceriaan", str_detect(metaphors, "dimension"))[["n"]])` token for `r happyr::scaps("object's dimension")` occurring with *keceriaan*. Let us now consider the insight offered by the distinctive collocates of *keceriaan* as shown in [Table \@ref(tab:colloc-res-keceriaan)](#colloc-res-keceriaan).

```{r colloc-res-keceriaan}
# present the result table for collocational analysis for *keceriaan*
happyr::mdca_attr(mdca_colloc, cxn_type = '^keceriaan') %>% 
  top_n(20, assocstr) %>% 
  left_join(happyr::dist_colloc_gloss, by = "collocates") %>% # left-join the gloss for the distinctive collocates
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  select(collocates, gloss, everything()) %>%
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3), 
         collocates = paste("*", collocates, "*", sep = "")) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = paste("The 20 most distinctive, 4-window span collocates for *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness' in the combined data sets (Indonesian Leipzig Corpora, IWaC Sketch Engine, and WebCorp)^[As explained in `**Chapter 3**`, the nominalised forms for ", happyr::scaps("ceria"), " and ", happyr::scaps("riang"), " occur in a very low frequency in the whole Indonesian Leipzig Corpora compared to the forms for the other concepts. Additional data for these forms are then culled from the *IWaC* of *Sketch Engine* and ten online Indonesian newspapers via *WebCorp*.].", sep = ""), row.names = TRUE)
```

Among the interesting finding is the distinctiveness of *anak(-anak)* 'child(ren)' to co-occur with *keceriaan*. This may invoke an 'innocent' or 'pure' quality of *keceriaan*. The presence of metaphorical collocate *mengembalikan* 'to *return/give back*' may relate to *korban* 'victims', who may lose their cheerfulness. Other distinctive collocates also indicate the associated setting for *keceriaan*, such as *sekolah* 'school', *pertunjukan* '(a) show', and *lebaran* 'Ramadhan'. These settings foreground more of the social characteristics of *keceriaan*, compared to the more competitive one as for *kegembiraan* 'joy'; however, the settings generally converge on the more public/wider scope of these two `r happyr::scaps("happiness")` concepts compared to *kesenangan* 'pleasure', which is more self-centred. Affective-related collocates for *keceriaan* include *kesegaran* 'freshness' and *semangat* 'enthusiasm', the latter of which can support the proposed argument for the liveliness, intense, and vibrancy of *keceriaan* 'cheerfulness'.

## Distinctive metaphors for *keriangan* 'cheer(fulness)' {#riang}

The distinctive metaphors for *keriangan* are set out in [Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-keriangan)](#distinctive-for-keriangan). The distinctive metaphors for the root-nominal *riang* 'very happy; joyous; glad' are filtered out given the AssocStr values are below the set threshold of 2 for the discussion. Also, both *keriangan* and *riang* have the least metaphorical tokens compared to the other synonyms within their respective morphological forms (N~*keriangan*~ = `r subset(synonym_token, synonyms == "keriangan")[["n"]]` and N~*riang*~ = `r subset(synonym_token, synonyms == "riang")[["n"]]`). For this reason, some of the results need to be interpreted with caution.

```{r distinctive-for-keriangan}
mdca_res %>%
  happyr::mdca_attr(cxn_type = "keriangan", min_assocstr = 2) %>% 
  mutate(exp = round(exp, 3L),
         metaphors = happyr::scaps(metaphors)) %>% 
  select(-synonyms) %>%
  knitr::kable(caption = "Distinctive metaphors for *keriangan* 'cheer(fulness)'", row.names = TRUE)
```

The intensity of *keriangan* can be inferred from its significant association with the `r happyr::scaps("contained entity")` metaphor, which is also distinctive for *keceriaan* (cf. [Table \@ref(tab:distinctive-for-keceriaan)](#distinctive-for-keceriaan)). *Keriangan* most frequently collocates with only one lexical unit (LU) type of the metaphor evoking 'fullness' of the Content in the following metaphorical pattern: _**penuh** (dengan) keriangan_ 'to be *full* of(/with) cheer(fullness)' (`r happyr::phd_data_metaphor %>% filter(str_detect(synonyms, "keriangan"), str_detect(metaphors, "contained entity")) %>% count(m_expr, sort = TRUE) %>% filter(n == max(n)) %>% .[["n"]]` tokens). This salient pattern reveals that *keriangan* is prominently talked about in terms of its 'intense' state (i.e., being full of it).

```{r distinctive-for-riang}
mdca_res %>%

  select(-synonyms) %>%
```

```{r colloc-res-keriangan}
happyr::mdca_attr(mdca_colloc, cxn_type = '^keriangan') %>%
```

```{r plot-metaphor-type-freq-per-syn, fig.cap = "Distribution of metaphor types per syonynyms againts their token frequency in metaphorical patterns.", echo = FALSE, include = FALSE}

# additional codes for visualising the relationship between the token frequency of the synonyms in metaphorical expressions and the number of metaphor types evoked. This is not part of the analysis in the thesis.

# Narration:
## [Figure \@ref(fig:plot-metaphor-type-freq-per-syn)](#plot-metaphor-type-freq-per-syn) visualises the relationship between the token frequency of metaphorical patterns for a given synonyms (*y*-axis) and the number of metaphor types evoked by the metaphorical patterns (*x*-axis).

metaphor_type_df <- happyr::phd_data_metaphor %>% 
  mutate(data_type = if_else(!str_detect(synonyms, "^ke.+an$"), "root", "nominalised")) %>% 
  group_by(synonyms, data_type) %>% 
  summarise(synonyms_tokens = n(),
            metaphor_types_per_synonyms = n_distinct(metaphors)) %>% 
  arrange(data_type, desc(synonyms_tokens))

metaphor_type_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = metaphor_types_per_synonyms,
             y = synonyms_tokens,
             colour = data_type,
             group = data_type)) +
  geom_text(aes(label = synonyms)) +
  xlim(c(0, 60)) +
  theme_bw()
```

```{r kendall-cortest, echo = FALSE, include = FALSE}
# code for computing correlation test between the token frequency of the synonyms in the metaphorical expressions and the number of metaphor types evoked. This is not part of the analysis in the thesis.
kendall_res <- cor.test(metaphor_type_df$synonyms_tokens, metaphor_type_df$metaphor_types_per_synonyms, method = "kendall", conf.level = 0.99, alternative = "greater")
```
